reviewText:
STAR WARS™ - Knights of the Old Republic™ – Adventure/RPG; Squad Tactics
a spoiler-free review

Rating: Recommended as Essential


You wake up on a battle cruiser during an all-out firefight, find your way to the escape pods when it gets severely damaged, fight your way through enemy soldiers and crash-land on an unfamiliar planet. Knights of the Old Republic [KOTOR] takes place some 4,000 years before the events of A New Hope; Yoda, Darth Vader, Obi-Wan Kenobi and Luke Skywalker are names of no consequence in the Star Wars universe. You are in completely new, unfamiliar territory here.

Star Wars fan or not, KOTOR is a game that everyone should play. A companion system ahead of its time, multiple storylines, rich dialogue and backstory, YELLOW lightsabers and a unique tactical approach to combat allow this installment in the Star Wars series of games to really shine.

- Companions -
You will meet several unique, diverse characters in your travels; a few of them can join your party. Grab two party members of your choice and your main character and hit the streets (or dunes, or forests, or whatever). These characters come with set attributes and skills, but when they level up (yes, there is a leveling/experience system; this is an RPG), you control how they improve.

- Story -
No spoilers here, don’t worry. There are a multitude of side-quests to complete that complement the main quest, backstories to explore for each of your party members, fascinating lore on the origins of a few prominent species and multiple storylines. Depending on dialogue decisions, you can earn either Light Side or Dark Side points, determining the final path your story takes.

- Cons -
Not too many of note. I clipped through the floor a couple times. A number of seemingly random fatal crashes. This game was put out in 2003, so it’s a little behind the times in visuals and the cutscenes are really cheesy. The camera is a bit tricky to figure out at first. If you’re not expecting tactical battles (give orders rather than do battle yourself), it can be quite confusing. The biggest thing is that your companions will, at times, slow down or stop when you’re not looking for no reason, preventing you from entering the next area.
The Bottom Line: None of these presents anything more than minor frustration; the game is well-built.

Well, that’s all I have to say about KOTOR. An aged but timeless classic that any Star Wars fan (and quite a few non-Star Wars fans) will enjoy.

Not Recommended
Recommended With Caution
Recommended
Highly Recommended
- Recommended as Essential


Fun Facts:
Developer: BioWare (Dragon Age: Origins, Baldur’s Gate, Mass Effect)
Release Date: July 18th, 2003
Soundtrack Composer: Jeremy Soule (The Elder Scrolls, Guild Wars 2, Total Annihilation)
Prominent Voice Actors: Ethan Phillips (Star Trek: Voyager, Benson), Jennifer Hale (Mass Effect 3, Baldur’s Gate), Steve Blum (Wolverine and the X-Men, Metal Gear Solid)

reviewText: I've put in way more hours into this game than Steam shows because I originally owned the actually discs (yes, physical discs) and later got the Steam version.  This is one of the greatest games ever.  An immersive storyline, interesting characters, great gameplay.  Despite its 2003 release date, and somewhat dated graphics, I still return to this game every so often to replay it.  Because of the branching story and different choices you can make (be evil, be good, kill this guy, steal this item, etc) each playthough is different.  I actually have a difficult time playing as an evil character because the game makes me feel bad about my decisions; very few games can do that!  There's also some funny moments, particularly anything that HK-47 says :)\n\nMake sure to get one of the widescreen hacks if you have a modern computer.

reviewText:
This review is based on a purely vanilla playthrough
+ Character creation allows stat customizations right from the get-go, and goes the extra mile by adding a 'recommended' button that offers balanced numbers based on class; useful feature for beginners
+ Very even and agreeable pace throughout the entirety of the game; never felt too fast, slow, or interspersed with filler content
+ Excellent, marvelous soundtrack; really keeps you in the game, and does well to make this title feel true to the franchise
+ Mercifully short load times
+ There are myriad available side-quests, all voiced
+ Combat mechanics are well thought-out (despite 'dice-roll' RNG, of which I am not normally fond, as a general rule) and give you plenty of room for creativity and finesse
+ Excellent story with lots of depth and freedom of choice
+ While some characters remained a bit two-dimensional throughout the game, the majority of them are adequately fleshed-out and seem to develop to some extend
+ The game includes a few optional minigames (eg. Pazaak Cards)
+ Multiple endings, based entirely around the player's decisions
+ Tons and tons of lore-friendly set-pieces and items (both practical and aesthetic)
+ Extremely, alarmingly mod-friendly
+ An absolute plethora of immersive dialogue options
+ Boasts a few masterful plot twists

- Poor camera; you get used to it, but it's initially quite frustrating and limited in functionality
- Poor inventory system; throws everything into one long list as you accumulate items, leading to lots of monotonous scrolling when looking for equipment (mostly a problem for fellow hoarders, you could just sell all of your junk)
- Mostly flat, uninspired voice-overs (some voice actors were of inordinately better quality, though that mostly served to highlight the disparity)
- AI movement is mostly terrible, leading to waiting for characters to catch up, and lots of blocked doors/paths
- Lots and lots of bugs and glitches; most notably terrain glitches and a few CTDs (some of this can be fixed with a small amount of modding, I'm told)
- The autosave function is too sparse in functionality, and has led to some extremely frustrating moments

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Also, feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
Before Mass Effect there was Knights of the Old Republic. Bioware, in 2003, decided to introduce a decision-making system which enabled you, the player, to align yourself with either the light or the dark side. Major plot decisions could be made and your gender could also yield different options during the conversations.

This is one of the things one can like in KotOR. The two different alignments enable you to have at least two different playthroughs. But you have many side missions anyway. Even the companions can give you some.

The world where the game takes place in shows us the previously unknown history of the Star Wars universe. A world that is 4,000 years before the films are taking place. You are awaken on a ship that is being attacked by Darth Malak. Your job is to escape, find companions, regroup and annihilate your archenemy. Of course, in the process you get to learn the Jedi way!

Do note that the game is round-based. You pick the actions necessary (though this is limited each round) and you can even pause at certain points. You can also make a decision on behalf of your companions - the choice is really yours. What I have found out about the game later on is that it is based on Dungeons and Dragons rules. And the actions are calculated in accordance with these rules. As to how successfully the dice were rolled and what modifications were applied to the damages you are not told - but this is accessible from a menu.

The game has excellent music (composed by Jeremy Soule), a long-lasting experience and, well, I wanted to say good graphics, but as the game has aged in the last 10 years or so, this is not really true anymore. Still, the art design is as Star Wars-esque as it can get and this being a Bioware RPG I highly recommend it. Not just for Star Wars fans or Bioware fans but to everybody wanting to have a good time!

reviewText:
“A Long Time Ago, in a Galaxy Far, Far Away…”
A war rages between The Republic and The Sith. ‘Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic’ throws you head first into a fantastic recreation of the Star Wars universe filled with lightsabers, Sith Lords, and political intrigue, in an immersive, gripping tale of Good vs. Evil which - more than a decade on - stands tall as one of the best RPG’s of its generation, and probably the finest gaming interpretation of the iconic Star Wars franchise.

Campaign: Released in 2003 by Bioware | Lucas Arts, and set 4000 years before the events in ‘Star War’s - Episode 1: The Phantom Menace’, ‘SW:KOTOR’ tells the tale of a relative unknown caught up in events of cosmic proportions. The opening credits thrust you into the midst of an inter-galactic battle between Republic forces and a Dark Sith Lord, which finds you crash landing onto an alien planet, trying to stay alive and escape an inter-planetary Sith blockade. An unusually strong connection with the Force catapults the player from by-stander to protagonist, as an engaging, story-fueled campaign takes you across the galaxy from the mysterious water-world of Manaan, to the desert planet of Tatooine among many others. A lovingly crafted universe is filled with lots of recognizable faces to include – the treacherous Hutt’s, Bounty Hunter’s, Sith, Jedi Knights, Wookies, Protocol Droids, Rancor’s, and Sand People - amongst a broader cast of nearly 300 distinctive alien races.

Gameplay | Graphics | Sound: A Third-Person RPG in the classic mold, gameplay in ‘SW:KOTOR’ is built around the 4 pillars of ‘Character Development and Customization’, ‘Inventory Management’, ‘Combat’, and ‘Dialogue-driven Story-Telling’. You choose to play as one of three character classes (Soldier, Scout or Scoundrel – with both male and female options available), and then as one of three Jedi sub-classes (Sentinel, Consular or Guardian). A deep inventory system allows you to customize and equip your character with a multitude of clothing, weapon and armor options as well as assign XP to level-up in a variety of areas from Attributes, Skills, Feats, and Force Powers. Combat is based around the ‘D20’ RPG rule-set popularized in ‘Dungeons and Dragons (D&D)’, and while round-based, players are able to queue up actions and run them simultaneously in real-time. Finally, Character interaction is via a dialogue menu that is rumored to contain over 2000 lines of text, clearly geared toward maximizing player choice across multiple playthrough’s. While the broad strokes are seemingly representative of standard RPG fare, three elements serve to distinguish this title from the rank and file – 1.  The ability to switch to | customize | play as any character in your group provides for great overall variety 2. The campaign is well-paced with ‘Third Person’ gameplay broken up by ‘Rail-shooting’, ‘Stealth’, ‘Racing’, and ‘Gambling’ mini-games and 3. Deep customization options, lots of side-quests and the sheer glee of roaming the Star Wars universe adds great replayability to this title. Sound Design is also particularly noteworthy, with voice-acting, sound effects and background score composition all top-shelf. Well optimized K&M controls round out a well polished title.

Flaws: There is little to gripe about here, and perhaps the game’s biggest ‘flaw’ is its dated graphics - which have not aged particularly well - but it’s a testament to the overall strength of this title that it remains not only playable, but immensely engaging, despite this. Other minor issues include somewhat repetitive combat, and some minor character pathfinding issues.

Overall, ‘Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic’ is an erstwhile classic from another time, rich in Star Wars lore, with a deep, engaging campaign, a fantastic background score, compelling combat mechanics, high replayability and filled with iconic characters, plot twists, and moral complexities. This is a title you could easily lose yourself in for 50-60 hours on a single-playthrough, and that’s even before player-choice dictates your ultimate path to the Light or Dark Side. The Force is all around you, Padawan. What is your Destiny? – Highly Recommended! – (Rating 9/10)

reviewText:
Alright, hands down my favorite Bioware rpg released ever.

A great story that allows serious plot changing options such as killing off companions or finding out their individual personal stories. Great graphics for the time period and some of the most entertaining star wars lightsaber combat, beaten only by the Star Wars Jedi Knight series. Not to mention the STELLAR voice acting.

With the recent announcement of EA purchasing the patent for KOTOR 3, this is a great item to pick up to get you into the realm of KOTOR.

But how much could they have changed compared to the realm of star wars might you say? A but ton that's what.

Ok to start with, the game takes place 4000 years before the movies and revolves around a wide spread jedi council. You are , (with as few spoilers as I can manage to describe this in) travelling across a set of 8 unique planets and locations where you can interact with tons of sidequests.

One more entertaining sidequest (Non Main Story Spoilers) on Manaan where you act as a lawyer/detective and attempt to prove a man in court either innocent or guilty. Which winds up being a lot more fun than expected due to the depth of the investigation process and the trial interactions.

However, I do have a few complaints about the game.

First, the beginning sequence is AWFUL. The first time through it is entertaining to an extent, but if you want to start a fresh playthrough, you are often discouraged due to the length and lack of interest the beginning sequence holds. Once you are off Taris(the starting planet) however, the game's pace drastically improves. (Note: However there are mods to solve this issue should you find them necessary)

Also, the main character is unvoiced, while it is kind of nice not having to hear one or two voices for all of your characters, the addition of voice and voice editor would have made the game that much better.

Let's also not forget the utter lack of animations. Let's see, the game has about 5 death animations, 2 talking animations and very ugly running animation. Leading to a severe lack of depth visually.

All other complaints I may think of are tiny things about the game that I take as a personal disliking based on taste, not anything that drastically affects the title.

Overall, pick up this game if you like RPGs. You won't be disappointed in the slightest.

Conclusion: I cannot speak for everyone

you can easily double your time spent.

reviewText:
So good! I was skeptical about the gameplay when I used to watch videos of this game but it works really well.
You have 20 levels to rank up jedi powers, combat skills and feats (your starting class determines which of these 3 categories gets the most points per level up). A jedi power available is force lightning, a combat skill is something like flurry which increases your number of attacks but they deal less damage and might not hit and a feat is which type of armour you can wear or other passive benefits.
Combat is played on a turn-based dice roll system which might sound off-putting but works out well. Throughout the game you will meet characters who join you on your spaceship and you may choose 2 of them to accompany you outside of the ship. Companions will have their own stats, gear and skills so you can play around this (if you come across a companion with high lockpicking you might choose not to level your own and swap to this companion to unlock things for you). You can choose to level up your companions skills manually or automatically.
You can choose preset combat manoeuvres for yourself and companions such as ranged attacking or jedi support (buffs and heals) or you can choose to manually decide you and your parties actions by pausing the combat and assign attacks and items to a queue. You also don't have to use companions at all, you can elect to play in a solo mode where all the exp gained from enemies will go straight to your character. You also don't have to worry about this mode because companions will automatically be boosted to your level if you haven't used them.
How you play the game is up to you. I went for a dual-lightsaber character with light armour and attack bonus jedi powers but you can play as a sniper, explosives expert, jedi caster or even unarmed fighting.
The story is really what made the experience for me however. You will travel to multiple planets, gain your own starship, meet interesting characters and get to interact with almost every NPC you come across with multiple lines of dialogue and character development.
One downside to this game is that you can't play in a widescreen resolution without using mods (although guides can be found for this on the forums here on steam, along with HD mods and many others).

reviewText:
Awesome story that has multible endings; light/dark side endings.
Very memorable characters, very good combat system.
Good Moral choices; choose to help people in trouble with bounty hunters/ect, help the man/woman in trouble, accept bribe and walk away, or help then demand payment, dark side/light side actions, let people go or kill them, etc.
Every decision you make affects the story and how the characters/world act and talk to you; light/dark side choices, killing off companions, choosing to help people or not changes things, etc.
Great level up system; can choose between many force powers, and melee or ranged weapon atacks/passives, many stats to upgrade, etc.
Very interactive companions; you get many companions as you play, what you do affects how they act and talk to you, some things you do before can affect if you even get some of them, you can talk to them and learn their history, and develop a mild romantic relationship with some of them, they fight and argue amongst themselves, etc.
Good variety of weapons; rifles, pistols (can duel wield), swords (can duel wield), duel-blade swords, lightsabers (can duel wield), double-blades lightsabers, gernades, mines.
Only complaint is the companions walk rather close to you at times and can trap you in a doorway, corner of a hallway, etc.

reviewText:
Star Wars KOTOR is regarded as one of the best RPG games of all time. I admit, it's not as grand and open as The Elder Scrolls or Fallout. It's closer to that of Dragon Age.

PROS:

The game is everything Star Wars
It opens up a whole new area of lore, events, story, characters not seen in the movies
It has a great RPG aspect, letting you choose your character, party, and slight storyline.
The game lets you decide the fate of some quests & how your party members get along with you and others.
A well-done karma system is also in place, letting you choose the light side or the dark side
You have a fully customizable character build, you star with selecting your base class, but can place your attribute and skill points where you wish.
Weapon usage is also your choice. Like blasters? Shoot some Sith. Swords? Slash some Sith. Lightsabers? SLice your foes with your badass laser stick!
LIGHTSABERS, who doesn't want one?!
[* Lightsabers are customisable with their crystals, changing stats and their colour.
[/list]


[b] CONS: [/b]

[list]
[*] Old graphics, but still looks beautiful. Could POSSIBLY get a texture mod somewhere. The game is also being fan remade (3rd and 1st person view) and will be available at some point.
[*] Nothing else, this game is near perfect.
[/list]

reviewText:
This is not only the game that got me into Bioware, but it might be my first RPG I actually tried to get good at and learn the mechanics of; setting the oath for my love of RPG's as a whole. It's not perfect and it can be argued if it aged well or not, but it's a lot of fun to play and has a great story if you let it suck you in.

The game itself follows the tried and tested D&D rules like many Bioware games, with this game using a variation of 3rd/3.5 Edition rules; at least that's what it reminded me of. Put simpler; Dexterity for guns, Strength for melee. Feats add to abilities, skills and the like and force users essentially get a magic bar and the choice of powers every few levels. There's also the use of the ever present Dark side/Light side choice in Star Wars. This is mainly to affect opinions of your team mates in some conversations, but it also provides cheaper Force use for certain powers if they conincide with your alignment (Spamming Lightning never became easier!). It's nice simple, it works. There are a few useless powers and feats, but really, that's subjective on my part and there's probably someone out there for every combination.

As for the atmosphere and world building, I won't go into too much detail. It's Bioware, by this point we all know that Bioware can excel at this. I will say though that by being set years before the movies, there's a nice chance to set up some new villains and situations that provide a nice background to everythgin; I'd say the whole story is a huge point in the games favour.

Like I said though, the games not perfect. It's hard to ignore that the levels you visist are essentially successions of corridor after corridor. There's one path that reaches the end, sometimes you divert off it for secrets, but the apth is always there. The game tries to disuguise this, and I admit, it took me a while to catch on, but it's there, and hard to ignore once you notice. Not to mention, without spoiling it, the end game can feel a little sloggish with how it handles itself. It can be fun, but your first time, without expecting it, prepare for a lot of reloads.

Still, despite all that, the game's a tonne of fun to play and I love to return to it once in a while. I'd easily say it's worth every penny and should be played by everyone at least once; wholeheartedly reccomended

reviewText:
General info
~Genre: Role playing game
~Number of players: 1
~Star Wars related product
~Completion time: 30-45 hours
~High replay value

Strong points
+Variety: Visit places with different geological maps, inhabitants, natural characteristics. Even the “tutorial” planet (Taris) is distinct from the others. You won't find repeatable patterns in this game. Each place has its own story to tell. My advice: Don't rush; take your time and explore.

+Music score: A plethora of modern games advertise the “quality” of their music. Mostly it's just a marketing trick. Knights of the Old Republic (KotOR) is an exception. The developers put a lot of effort to capture their product's atmosphere in a music sheet. Example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pD4YUEd18R0

+Story: “Memorable characters” is a cliché. Numerous titles brand the term in their case cover but only a few actually deserve it. KotOR does. Don't take my word for it. Just try the game and see if Juhani, Jolee or Canderous won't leave a mark on you. This will be a tale about partnership, trust, love, hatred, grief, revenge, anger, maturity, and reckoning.

+Liberating experience: This is a game of more actions that words. Albeit a role playing game, KotOR pushes players to be responsible and pick their own path. Every character has a background and follows a moral code. Your protagonist's choices will reflect upon your companions in more than one ways. Aid them and they will aid you back. Betray their trust and see what happens in the course of the story. The game allows you to be whoever you want to.

+Grey: Despite being a Star Wars game, KotOR isn't a monotony of light and dark side choices. You can pick grey as easily as you can pick black or white. In that aspect it surpasses even the films in some instances. Are the Jedi the just order and Sith their everlasting evil counterbalance? Are the terms good and bad viable in such context?

+Micro-management: Pause the action anytime and give your commands to any member of your team. Sometimes, such management is the difference between success or… reloading the game. Just press “Space” (by default) during combat.

+Working bench: Forge weapons, enhance armor efficiency and even craft your own lightsaber piece by piece.

+Blend in: Not a Star Wars fan? No problem, neither am I. The story takes you 4,000 years before the events of the first film trilogy. You will meet individuals never seen before and you shall witness how certain groups became infamous in after years. Even if you have never heard of Star Wars before, you will still be able to enjoy the game to the fullest.

+Living in the parallel: Fan of Star Wars? This game is for you. You will recognise many familiar patterns. Be alert though: Darth Vader and Darth Malak despite playing a similar role in the two stories they don't necessarily serve the same purpose.

+Side questing: Tired of mundane sidequests which involve killing massive amount of weak enemies, fetching items from borings NPCs and ultimately rewarding the player with useless items and questionable currency? From saving a captive spy to playing the attorney for the shake of an old friend, KotOR will make you remember each completed side quest.

+Narration: KotOR is one of those games that utilizes your imagination to some extent instead of showing you everything through a cut-scene or an FMV. Listen to your teammates stories, close your eyes and imagine being there with them; in their old tales of youth and inexperience. Gaming as it should be.

+Price: Even if you can't wait for a sale, buying it at full price worths it.

Weaknesses
-Old school dice: KotOR utilizes some mechanics which younger gamers won't recognize or are too lazy to study them for a few hours, such as invisible dice and hidden statistical factors. As a result, if you don't plan your character carefully you might be unable to finish the game. It is advisable to consult some guides before starting a new game.

-Graphical issues: This game might be unplayable in Windows 7 or later versions. One common solution is to turn off the grass on graphic options and disable movies. If that doesn't fix the issue (as it did for me on Windows 8.1) consult the helping and friendly community here on Steam.

-Limited customization: Unfortunately, the only body part that you are given a choice to meddle with (at the character selection section) is the face; not even the head generally. NPCs suffer from the same banality as well.

My rating4.5/5
I'm not a Star Wars fan. Nevertheless, this game reminded me of how a proper title must be developed. Forget the flashy trailers and bright packages. This is gaming at its finest. After 20 years of gaming experience, I feel content to include this game amongst my favourites.

reviewText:
One of the best games I've ever played. Seriously.
Skip to the bottom if you want a TL;DR.
According to Steam I've only played 23 hours' worth – that's not true. I've always had weird problems with the whole connection with Steam – one day it'll say I've played 31 hours, the next it'll say I've only played 7. I am pretty sure I've logged over 40 hours of gameplay on this.
Not much, when you compare it to other people's times. But I'm not a hardcore gamer. I game when I have some spare time.
This game is seriously good.
Sure, the combat is a bit odd and clunky, especially if you're used to modern games or if you don't role-play, but give it a bit and it'll feel natural. I actually prefer it.
The story is gripping, the characters well-developed.
It really does it's job in inserting you into the Star Wars universe, and story wise I have no complaints.
One complaint I do have is the length of time you spend running around. It's at least seventy percent of the game. And for some reason it just feels like a real drag.
TL;DR?
Excellent game, story is brilliant, role-play-style combat system, too much running around.

reviewText:
This is a great classic star wars game.

There are 3 different classes with different skills and abilities.
You better google search for more details on that, might be a little too complex for this review.

For example, in certain situations, depending on your abilities, you might be able to intimidate or pursuade people, repair or hack some machinery to help you out, unlock certain doors and containers.

There are blasters, melee weapons (swords and lightsabers) and different grenades to use in combat.
Aside from that, there is also a variety of force powers you can use, though you have to unlock those abilities with skill points first.

Combat is turn based and pausable, so you can plan out fights pretty well.
You can switch between your main character and his companions (if you have any) and control their actions in battle - Or you just let the game do it for you.

Companions level up as well, and you can upgrade their skills accordingly.

Might wanna check some gameplay on youtube if you wanna see what it's exactly like.

A lot of times in the game you have to make decisions, which either give you light side or dark side points. This also has an impact on how people react towards you.
(Just a heads up: Being a good guy is way more tiresome and expensive. Just kill everyone.)

The game runs perfectly for me on Windows 8.1 Professional 64 bit, the only little annoying bug I had fixed itself when turning on V-Sync, though I can't guarantee. Some people have reported problems. You should check out the community hub for that.

Any more questions? Feel free to leave a comment.

reviewText:
Wo fang ich an .. ?
Als ich SW:KotoR zum ersten Mal auf der Xbox Classic gespielt hab, war ich ca. 10 Jahre alt.
Ich hab das Spiel damals immer und immer wieder durch gespielt ! Nach ca 10 Jahren sah ich das die Star Wars Collection im Angebot ist und hab natürlich zugeschlagen. In dieser Box war zu meinem Glück SW:KotoR 1 & 2 dabei und dachte mir sofort das ich sie unbedingt wieder spielen muss !

SW:KotoR 1 ist damals wie heute einfach ein RPG MEILENSTEIN, das Spiel hat eine wirklich sehr gut geschriebene Story die ein jedesmal von neuem fesselt egal wie oft man das Spiel durchspielt. Nach jedem Playthrough finde ich immer wieder Quests und Dialoge die ich noch nie gesehen hab.

So jetzt noch eine kurze erklärung vom Spielverlauf:
Man erstellt sich am Anfang vom Spiel ein Charackter. Man wählt die Klasse aus verteilt paar Talentpunkte, bestätigt und es folgt Star Wars typisch ein kleines Intro die, die Handlung vom Spiel kurz erklärt. Man startet auf einem Raumschiff das sozusagen als Tutoriallevel funktioniert, in dennen die Spielemechaniken erklärt werden.
Die Kämpfe sind Rundenbasiert wärend man sich auf Nah- oder Fernkampf spezialisieren kann. Dabei wird man immer mit 2 weiteren Charackteren begleitet die man im Verlauf des Spieles findet. In dem Spiel gibt es eine Gut-Böse Mechanik, sprich alles was man tut oder nicht tut hat Folgen auf den Verlauf des Spieles.

Nun folgt noch eine kleine Warnung:
Das Spiel ist frustrierend verbuggt auf Windows 7, ohne gewisse Einstellung und Fixes die man sich aus dem Internet zieht crasht das Spiel fast nach jedem neuen Level (Planet).

Deswegen möchte ich noch einmal einige Tipps mitgeben die mir beim spielen geholfen haben:

- Im SW:KotoR Ordner gibt es eine Datei die seconfig.exe" heißt
date: dort müsst ihr unbedingt die Hardware-Maus deaktivieren.\nWenn bei euch das Spiel crasht wenn eigentlich eine Video abspielen sollte
recommended: müsst ihr leider die Videos deaktivieren.\n\n- Im selben Ordner gibt es eine Datei die sich "swkotor.ini" nennt dort geht ihr unter "[Graphics Options]" und stellt "FullScreen=1" auf "FullScreen=0". Ausserdem fügt ihr "AllowWindowedMode=1" in der untersten Zeile von [Graphics Options] ein. Diese aktiviert den Fenster Modus des Spieles
hoursPlayed:
da es im Fenstermodus weitaus stabiler läuft.

- Hier nochmal ein Video auf Englisch der das hier alles nochmal erklärt + einem Fix zum downloaden : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m6QE4WB1y14

- Das alles fixt jedoch nicht eines der nervigsten Bugs im Spiel: nach einem Kampf kommt es vor das der Charackter sich nicht mehr bewegen kann. Das liegt daran der er noch im Angriffsmous steckt obwohl keine Gegner in der nähe sind.
Was dagegen hilft:
* Wenn du Glück hast ist noch ein Gegner in der Nähe die diesen Bug beheben können.
* Manchmal hilft es einfach mit einem Bgleiter kurz zu reden.
* Aber am effektivsten ist es einach zu speichern un neu zu laden.

Das sind wirklich die einzigen Bugs die man merkt und wer über sie hinwegsehen kann

reviewText:
Even today, KOTOR I stands as an excellent example of what an RPG can be, and strongly breaks the assertion that all movie-licensed video games are terrible and cash-grabs. It isn't just a great RPG or a great entry of the Star Wars universe, but is also and quite simply a great video game that can be enjoyed by a wider audience than just RPG and Star Wars fans.

Story is an EXTREMLY important part of this game, and a highlight to that as well. You are a Republic soldier on a ship called the Endar Spire, and your goal is to escape before the Sith destroy it. You crash land on the planet Taris, and your adventure unfolds through exploration, character-development, and revelation. Choice is present in this game as well, adding replay-value as well. I cannot give away much about the story without spoiling the game, and it is best to experience it for yourself. Personally, I had no qualms with it, and the game stays true to the Star Wars universe while adding flavours of its own. The setting of 4000 years prior to the movies also makes it so you can appreciate the story without any past knowledge of Star Wars. I would even dare to say that this game easily triumphs over the stories of the movies.

How about gameplay? It is a turn-based game with many different weapons (from ranged to melee), powers and abilities that can be disposed against the enemy, and thankfully this game has a lot of different foes to defeat. The layers of strategy are quite endless, as you always have two squad-mates present at any time. Do you charge into battle while they cover you with gun-fire? Do you all throw grenades to make quick work of your foes? Difficulty options are also present, which are nice as some weapon configurations can allow you to be a god while others will leave you crying for mercy. Luckily with squad-mates, this is really a non-issue. There are also side activities, called swoop racing and pazzak, which are fun side games that provide replayability.

Also a side note, but combat can be paused to issue commands, and you watch the action unfold. Modifiers can allow you to deal more/less damage, and you can even miss, as the game has a dice-roll mechanic in its turn-based formula.

As for graphics, the game is clearly dated by today's standards. In terms of art style, this game is spot on. It retains Star Wars' signature look and style, and developer BioWare has added their own flair and style to it, making the game stand out in this department, and being memorable to that. This can also be said for the sound, which is indentical to what you would expect from the franchise. Lasers to lightsabers all sound spot-on, and both the soundtrack and voice work are fantastic as well.

In terms of replayability, the great story and presence of choice already make it a game that you can put multiple playthroughs into. There are also many side quests and lore that you can delve into, and maybe you'll see something that you didn't see before on a second or third playthrough. Even the gameplay can offer up different experiences depending on how you play. My run of the game was about 31 hours, and this was ignoring most side-quests, so you will find your money's worth at $10.99, especially if this game goes on sale.

Honestly, this is one of few games I can say I didn't have any personal issues with. Others may differ in opinion, but to me KOTOR was flawless. If you're a Star Wars or RPG fan, this game is a MUST BUY. I'd strongly reccomend it to anyone, however the combat mechanics may turn some off, especially if you loathe RNG. However, in this particular game it comes off as natural and is perfectly fine, unlike the TES III Morrwind combat system, as it is turn-based. If I had to rate this game out of 10, it would definitely be a 10/10, but like every game it does have mechanics that have the potential to be even better.

reviewText:
Rank: 9/10
Recommendation(s): Like Star Wars, RPG games, and old school game mechanics.
Major Theme: This old title shows us how games should be made.
Bought at Price: $10.99

I have over a thousand hours on Dota 2, 700+ on Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, and more than enough on Garry's Mod. So why would I play this game if I have plenty of hours on my other games? There's a simple reason for this.

Bioware. Yes, the timely company turned EA division, makes this game great.

While this game will prove a challenge for people who want non-stop action, this classic title has to be one of the most solid RPG games, if not PC titles ever made. Before I got a Steam account, I played this game with CDs (yes real CDs).

There's actual content to the story, and the plot is well thought out and executed. Your actions will have consequences, and will either lead you down to the light or dark side of the force. Beyond just simple dark vs. light, the game offers other ways of having a unique experience.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=480619533
Using your repair and computer skills, you can clear rooms filled with enemies, or fix up and alter a robot to fight for you. Want to avoid enemies? There's a stealth skill for that. Want to avoid fights in a bar? The persuasion skill is your go to skill. Maybe you even want to have the most powerful force powers available to you? There's a way to go about that as well. The only limiting part of the game is base story, which should be entertaining and engaging. It can be a little dry, as there is a lack of humor, but this title does very well considering its ESRB rating (Mass Effect isn't in the same boat).

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=436449755
As always, it wouldn't be a Bioware game without companions. Each offers something unique, and will progress your back story which isn't mandatory.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=481536576
Downsides? Well every game has some which isn't surprising. For being an old title, the graphics are very simple. If you failed to notice the processor requirement of an Intel Pentium 3, then I'm not sure what to say. There's nothing you can really do to improve the graphics of the title, but there are certainly ways to modernize them. By default the game is only compatible with a 4:3 ratio monitor. By using third-party utilities, you can resolve this and get a better experience with a now standard 16:9 monitor.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=427275987

Being an old school game, it does have all the “attributes” available. Yes, you will have to micro manage things like points in “wisdom” and “dexterity”. If you want to avoid all of that, play with the “auto upgrade” button. The game does also have a “dice roll” system, where there are chances to miss/hit and not do complete damage. Mass Effect 1 carried on from this, in case you were wondering where that game got its mechanic from.

All in all, this title should impress you for being so old, yet being so solid. Why games aren't being made like this anymore, who knows..

reviewText:
Despite dodgy AI from non-primary characters, it's still an incredibly timeless game with a great story and a great expansion on Star Wars lore.

Feat progression for each individual class can be confusing for first-timers but if attention is paid, it's all quite easy to pick up on. The ability to choose to gravitate towards the Light or Dark side of the Force is fantastic; as is the ability to choose Force powers to go with your choice (ie. Light side powers involve buffing, Dark side powers have things such as Choke and Force Lightning). Obviously the Dark side is a lot more fun, simply due to the dialogue options you have available, the ability to earn a lot more coin and the joy of choking your enemies.

Great game.

reviewText: The gameplay feels out of date by today's standards, but it's very similar to a turn based rpg.  Skill points are scarce enough to make you feel like you're making real choices upon level up (a common feature of older rpgs).  I found the game to be challenging, but easy mode should let you get through if you just want to experience the story.  The story is incredible and that's what makes this game a must play.   It took me a little bit to get into the game, but I eventually got hooked.   There's multiple endings so playing the game through twice just to get very different endings is worth it.  This game is worth the standard price, but if you ever see it on sale PICK IT UP!

reviewText:
Star Wars KOTOR is an RPG made by the RPG masters at Bioware. As a fan of Star Wars myself, I was excited to finally play this game. I've heard really good things about this game and I was not let down by this game.

Pros:
+The Story.... MY GOSH THE STORY (I won't spoil a thing because its that good)
+The morale system that greatly affects the story, characters, atmosphere, and ending.
+The characters feel three dimensional with their extensive backstories and colorful personalities.
+The background lore to this game is really well done and when you look at it closley you'll see the parallels to the movies
+The design of the locations is top-notch
+Gives a more in-depth look at the Star Wars universe.

Cons:
-Graphics look a little dated, but not too bad.
-The Real Time combat got boring to me after a while (although this is something that I don't like in RPGs in general)
-It had to end

Overall, (9.7/10) This game is a masterpiece and it is a must-buy to all Star Wars fans.

P.S. To me this game is canon, I'm looking at YOU DISNEY!!!!!!

reviewText:
TL;DRA must play for Star Wars and/or RPG fans.
+ Compelling plot
+ Dialogues (apart from Aliens' lines)
+ Characters
+ Classes
+ Force powers and skills
+ Option of choosing between the light and the dark side
+ Lots of items
+ Soundtrack
+ Minigames
- Bugs! Bugs everywhere! (Saving often and in different slots is highly recommended)
- Camera and movement
- Neutrality is punished here

REVIEW
Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is a well-acclaimed RPG made by Bioware. Its action is set 4000 years before the Galactic Empire. The war between the Republic and the Dark Sith Lord named Malak is raging. The protagonist is merely a Republic soldier at first, but, as the story progresses, he/she starts to play a much more important role. It turns out that the main character has a strong connection to the Force and has to train as a Jedi.

The player can choose between three classes for the protagonist: Soldier (expert in combat), Scoundrel (rogue), Scout (jack of all trades), and, later on, 3 Jedi classes: Guardian (focus on lightsabre combat), Consular (focus on Force powers), and Sentinel (jack of all trades). Every class has its own strengths and weaknesses and require a different approach so choose wisely.

The main hero will not travel alone. There are a few characters who will join him on the journey. Every companion has a story and motives behind them so it is worth to talk with them. Moreover, they add yet another layer to the rich plot.

The gameplay is focused on doing quests, visiting planets, levelling, and, of course, combat. The game's mechanics are based on D&D 3.5. Fortunately, it is made accessible even to the players who are new to RPGs. There is a huge variety of skills, feats, and Force powers at your disposal which definitely contributes to longevity of the game. Most of the time, the player leads a small group (with up to two companions) and ventures forth. All characters are controllable and while they seem to do well enough on their own, there are issues with pathfinding and sometimes the characters get stuck. This is particularly noticeable in locations with tight corridors.

Throughout the game, the player will have make many decisions. The choices can have a huge influence on the outcome. This is one of the biggest strengths of the game. Speaking of the freedom of choice, the player is able to choose between the light and the dark side as they see fit. Earning light side points make using the light Force powers cost less and using the dark ones cost more and vice versa. This is one of the first games where being the bad guy is just as doable as being the saviour of the Galaxy. While remaining relatively neutral is possible, it is not a very viable choice. For instance, there are some items which are restricted to either side of the Force spectrum. Moreover, the player more often than not will be forced to join one side of a conflict or to take some action. Be wary of your choices, for the Galaxy is at stake!

Saving the Galaxy (or dooming it to fall) can be exhausting. Worry no more, for there is a lot to do in your free time. Apart from a myriad of side-quests, there also are minigames, namely pazaak (blackjack on steroids) and swoop racing. Not only they are enjoyable but also can give you extra credits.

However, there are some serious technical issues. The game is utterly crawling with bugs*. For instance, it is not an uncommon occurrence when the dialogues start to skip. Restarting the game and reloading a previous save seems to help, but it is a glitch worth mentioning. What is more, teammates may sometimes stop attacking the foes. While I have not found any gamebreaking bugs, it is very sensible to save often and in different slots** just in case. Speaking of downsides, I am not particularly fond of the camera and movement. It is not bad per se, but it may take a while to get used to. And last but not least, there are few Aliens' dialogue lines so they get extremely repetitive after some time.

Concluding, this is one of the best RPGs I have ever played. Its compelling plot alone makes it outstanding and the decision-making adds to its replay value. If you do not mind dated graphics and are able to get past the technical issues, the game will reward you with a memorable experience. They just do not make games like they used to... A 9.5/10.


*Yes, I am aware it's a terrible pun. I apologise.
**Yes, you've heard it right: you can save whenever you want and in different slots. It used to be an industry standard" back in a day. No silly checkpoints and such. The saves are stored on your HDD.

P.S. Please check out my other reviews here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/FinnVArthur/recommended/

KotOR II review: http://steamcommunity.com/id/FinnVArthur/recommended/208580/"

reviewText:
For those having problems with loading the first part of the game: Go to Options, advanced options, go to graphics, go to advanced, and disable Frame Buffer Effects.

Now to the review.

Pros:
+Good character voice acting
+Pretty decent graphics for it's time
+Jeremy Soule (Music composer for this game) who also did the work on Skyrim did a marvelous job
+Great atmosphere. Everything is very well designed and well-placed.
+Fantastic Story
+Great game length (about 40 hours)
+Very Replayable
+Good combat
+Great main Villian
+Amazing and lovable characters
+Pretty fun sidequests

Cons:
-Starts off a little slow. But in my experience, most fantastic games do.
-Money is a ♥♥♥♥♥ to come by in the early stages of the game.
-After you beat the game, you cannot continue. SO DO ALL SIDEQUESTS IF YOU EVEN CONSIDER DOING THEM
-Takes over your life
-Puzzles are often complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Luckily, there aren't many of them.

If you like Star Wars, get this game. if you like kickass stories, get this game. This is a classic and a must-play. Enjoy! :)

reviewText: There are countless positive reviews on how this is one of the most brilliant RPG's ever made so I am just going to touch on a few things and lend a few quick pointers to people who are brand new to Kotor. The first thing to note is that the game is quite buggy, crashes occur at random and minimizing will periodically result in a crash as well. There are not enough auto saves in the game so SAVE OFTEN. This will prevent some serious frustration. The second thing to note is that the start of the game can be difficult to sink your teeth into. You may find your interest is not aroused immediately, just remember to give it time. I had to put the game down several times at the beginning as my interest waned. Come back with a fresh mind and push through and you will soon find the game much more immersive and rewarding after you contend with the beginning. Knights of the Old Republic is the Baldur's Gate of Star Wars games and is one of the greatest RPG's ever made. A no brainer for RPG enthusiasts and Star Wars fans.

I honestly don’t know what to write.....this game is fantastic!!! I strongly recommend this game, it’s fun and there is nothing more that can be said!! xD It’s an RPG with Star Wars Content, what more could you possibly ask for!!!

Now in all honesty, let me elaborate a bit more.
Firstly it’s an RPG game so anyone into RPG stop and take a look; that it’s Star Wars is just an amazing bonus…..it’s not like a cherry on the cake, it’s like a second cake. The game is smooth, rich and with loads of content in both gameplay and story as well as a massive roster of character each unique and extremely fun in their own way. Secondly its unique, for everyone u can go to any world in any order you want, you can have your own team, you create your own main characters. It’s a world of your own fantasy.

A 10/10 game an amazing execution for a game.

reviewText:
One of my favourite games of all time and the greatest Star Wars game ever released.

I probably will get downvotes for this, but when I bought this game at launch, I had never actually seen the Star Wars movies (I spend more time gaming, instead of movies), so I only knew the basics. This game (+Star Wars Galaxies) made me like the Star Wars franchise and watch the movies. You could compare Star Wars Knights Of The Old Republic to Mass Effect, also made by Bioware.

What makes SW:KOTOR such a great game to me is without a doubt the story. The choices you (have to) make, good vs bad, light side vs dark side and one of the best endings I've ever seen in any game. Most of the npc's are interesting and you build relationships with them, as the story progresses.

Obviously, the graphics have aged over the years but It still manages to make the Star Wars universe feel alive. For example, there are space ships flying around, even though they only consist of a few pixels, you still know what they are and makes the world feel more alive.

Combat is semi turn-based and often relies on tactical thinking. You are able to play KOTOR in real-time but you will probably die often.

Like I said before; Star Wars Knights Of The Old Republic, mainly relies on the story. Unless you are a real Star Wars fan, this game is not recommended for players who rather have great combat but for anyone else this game is one everyone should have played, before they are dead.

reviewText: Star Wars - Knights of the Old Republic is the astoundingly memorable classic from Bioware during their prime. They did everything perfectly; The world building is stellar with interesting characters and fleshed out worlds. A story that just stands out against many other games carrying the Star Wars title. The soundtrack still holds up thanks to the phenomenal work of Jeremy Soule.\n\nKeeping this simple and short, if you are a fan of Star Wars then this is a must buy.

reviewText:
I'm aware I don't have many hours logged on this game for the PC. However, as kid I played this on the original Xbox back in the day. So trust me on this.

1.) This game is by far my favorite in the Star Wars series, it's unique RPG style was unlike any game at the time (at least for me.) The choices you made in-game defined your character from the Jedi, Sith or even the interesting/unique Grey jedi and each choice could impact in small/ large ways the overall outcome of the story and your companions which makes for a lot of replay value.

2.) The story (without spoilers of course) is very compelling and complex with many new challeneges as you progress further and even a few twists and turns that keep the story exciting and not dragged out. The characters are interesting and fun to learn more about once you start forming bonds with them through your adventures.

3.) Turn based combat which is interesting and though wasn't my favorite style of combat, the formula for this game just feels right and flows well for what it is. It makes weapon modifications, skills and talents, armor and modifications and even the choice of companions important based on the enemies you may face in each and every encounter.

4.) Just buy this game! it's worth it. If you like a game where you create your own path, then make one in this beautiful universe of Knights of the Old Republic. Years have aged this game but it's a hidden gem you can't find anywhere else.

reviewText:
Star Wars: tKotOR  is one of the greatest rpgs ever made. It is a truly magical delve into the Star Wars universe, with an expansive story, interesting characters, and challenging turn-based gameplay. The game has some of the best roleplay elements extantt o date and allows for the player to go far above and beyond the typical black/white morality of many morality-driven  rpgs.

That all being said, the Steam version does not work. A quick google search will show you just how broken and unplayable this version of the game is. There has been no attempt to update this game for modern computers and even in compatability mode, it does not function. There are literally thousands of game-breaking bugs and glitches in the steam version that make it unplayable.

Please, please, play this game but for the love of god, save yourself the frustration and do not buy the Steam version. Wait for a sale on GOG. Steam couldn't care less about how this game does not work.

reviewText: There are very few games out there that I would declare 10/10 games, this is one of them. Ever since the original Star Wars trilogy ended 30 years ago we have been given lackluster successors to the trilogy in both film and video game. Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic is a game that really captures the narrative sense of adventure and good vs evil that made the original three films such joys to watch. (SPOILERS AHEAD) The characters you interact with are for the most part a very strong point of the game. Carth is a tortured character you really to have to spend a lot of time to understand. Bastilia is a gifted Jedi who is attempting to be the emotionless patient Vulcan-like Jedi we have come to known in the prequel films which makes it all the more fun to really get her angry at you. Mission Vao and Zaalbar are basically Chewbacca and Han solo if Han was a 13 year old girl. Jolee Bindo is one of the more interesting Jedi you’ll ever encounter; he’s not a member of the Jedi order and dodges any attempts you make to probe his character. Canderous Ordo is a perfect specimen of a Mandalorian (the human version of Predators) and is a combat veteran. You get two droids on your adventures, T3 who is basically R2-D2 and my favorite companion HK-47, a assassin droid who refers to all non droids as “Meatbags” and who you’ll learn is responsible for the deaths of all his previous masters. Oh and if you run into someone called “Juhani” just kill her, it saves you a lot of time. The Combat of this game is turn-based and as you gain more levels you are able to spec into a variety of different abilities which will give you new options when it comes to fighting enemies. However the calling card of this game is the story (MAJOR, GAME RUINING SPOILERS AHEAD). The game leads you to believe at first you are a Republic (insert class here) stationed on a ship orbiting Taris and it is up to save the galaxy by rescuing the Jedi leader of the ship’s expedition who was lost on the planet following an attack by the main enemy of the game Dark Malak. You then learn after you escape the planet you learn that you are gifted and can learn the powers of the Force. You take this as simply coincidence and continue on your journey to stop Malak (M. NIGHT SHAMALYAN SPOILERS AHEAD, LAST CHANCE TO TURN BACK). However in one of the greatest plot twists in video games, you learn that your character is actually “Darth Revan” the former master of Malak whose memory was changed by the Jedi Council. Now while this game is my favorite of my all time favorites it does have its faults. There are extra quests in the game that are just not do able unless you so happen to do planets in exact orders, the first two planets (Taris and Dantooine) are major drags to get through and are not the most enjoyable things to get through. Despite this, Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic is the greatest Star Wars game to exist and is easily worth the 10 dollars.\n

reviewText: Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is a team-based third person RPG set in the distant past of the Republic in the Star Wars universe. It is an excellent game, and a great RPG in the vein of other Bioware RPGs. Mechanically, it is a little dated and can take some getting used to, and the early portions of the game can drag a little bit, but once you get to the meat of the game, it's one of the best RPGs of all time, and a truly, truly excellent game.\n\nIt's been some time since I played through it, so I'm afraid the details have faded, but it's really a must-play for fans of the genre or of Star Wars. It's one of the best Star Wars properties which has ever been made, and it's a great game that stands up even a decade later.

reviewText:
Before I start this review I'd like to say that this isn't the first time I have played this game as I played it a while back on the original Xbox and I just had to buy it again for PC because 1. The PC graphics are slightly better 2. The mods you can download are AMAZING and 3. I just had to.. its star wars okay I just had to, So lets get started with this review and firstly lets talk about the gameplay.

Gameplay: At first it took me sometime to get used to playing this on PC with the mouse and keyboard but I adapted quickly to it and to be perfectly honest I prefer playing it this way than on the Xbox simply because it is sooo much easier to click on which enemy you want to attack rather than scrolling through each enemy with a gaming controller and also navagating the menu's on PC is highly superior and its pretty obvious why. The combat in this game is fun most of the time as you would issue a command and your characters will carry out that command without you having to mash buttons or whatever kind of like a Final Fantasy game but in more of a real time than that, but at times it can be very repetitive and enemies can just get annoying as it feels like they are stopping you from carrying out the story but this is just a minor grip with the gameplay as most of the time I felt very happy with the combat its just certain areas in the game the enemies get a little tendious (Damn Khath Hounds.)

Story: Well this is definetly the strongest part of the game as it is a Bioware game (Known for  the Mass effect series, Dragon Age and Jade Empire) and when you buy a Bioware game you know the story is going to be good and in this case the story is DAMN GOOD. I won't give anything away story wise but something happens later on that made my jaw drop. Overall story wise this game has a ton of sub plots as well such as the characters you interact with that come along with you on this journey all have their own back stories that mostly impact the main plot in some way and are also very interesting (well mostly).

Graphics: The graphics of this game are very good for its time and I think they still hold up today I mean it is a dated game so its not going to look amazing but with some extra mods you can download the game looks even better and theres nothing bad I can really say about this.

Overall verdict: Well I would say if you enjoy games that are heavily focused on story and if you love Star Wars (who doesn't) this is a must buy.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Options when talking to people are fantastic
- Quests are fun
- RPG elements are very good
- Character shaping is really fun (what kind of character your going to be)
- So much replayablity
- Great story with unique planets to go to

Cons:
- AI can get really annoying (especially when they corner you and you cant move
- If you move really fast through the story and you are under leveled it can be really unforgiving on some missions (constantly missing your attacks)

Over all fantastic RPG and its my personal favorite Star Wars game definitely recommend to anyone who love/likes Star Wars or who love/likes RPG's

reviewText: I'll admit...I was hesitant to even play this game at first.  I am a massive Star Wars fan, I loved the Mass Effect Trilogy (minus the ending of Mass Effect 3), and I think Bioware is a good developer. However, for some strange reason, I couldn't muster myself to play this game, even with my brother convincing me this is the best Star Wars game ever...and one of the best RPGs ever. So, I bought this game, but the download failed, so I thought I would be in for a rough ride with crashes. I redownloaded it, and I can safely say now that this game deserves all the praise it gets.\nThis game just simply plays great, and like many games like Half Life 2, Ocarina of Time, and others, this game stands the test of time. There is plenty of choice involved in both conversations and the way you play the game, and the combat itself plays wonderfully. Though, like most Bioware games, the story is top-notch. While I got this game on sale, I would still recommend it for the regular asking price...it is just that good. While I haven't played a whole lot of it so far, I am going to come back to it as quickly as I can...which is a testament to how great this game is. Buy this game, this is definitely the best Star Wars game I have played so far.\n

reviewText: his WRPG brought to you by Bioware was a stunning release for its time and playing it really shows you where their newer games have come from. But how does it stand up to some of the standards set by their newer RPGs? Pretty well, in fact; however, there were some pretty major annoyances and some issues I did have with the game. For starters, I just got done playing Planescape: Torment, and that WRPG (released 4 years earlier) had infinitely better decision making paths than KotOR did. I recognize that this *may* be due to the confines of working in the Star Wars universe: you have the Dark Side and the Light Side - each contrary to the other, but really I felt it could have been done better. Your options in KotOR seem to boil down to A) I'm going to help you out or B) I'm going to be a huge ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Example: You are in the slums and you have the ability to save a race of people for light side points. The dark side path is you can sell them out to some junk dealer because he wants to keep his profits up *for a measly 100 credits*! Just to let you know, that's not a lot of credits. And if you don't pick a side and want to stick in the middle path then guess what, no awesome light/dark side affiliated equipment for you sir! Speaking of roleplaying, if you decide you want to roleplay as a blaster user then you're going to have a bad time. As I said, I just got done with Planescape and I figured, why not go a charasmatic path" like I did in that game. Well

reviewText: In this classic game by Bioware you play as Dash Rendar, a sassy, no-nonsense mercenary and smuggler. The goal of this game is to go around and try to become a Pokemon Pazaak master. However, most of the time you are aimlessly drifting around alien worlds, and solving other people's meaningless problems.\n\nBut I know why many of you are reading this, and so I'll cut to the most important bit of information, you don't get a lightsaber until 5 hours into the game. A silly oversight by Bioware Corp, but what's even sillier is the fact they completely forgot this important piece of equipment in this game's sequel, Mass Effect! You know why Shepard ultimately failed in that series? Because he didn't have a damn lightsaber. There, I said it.

reviewText:
The story is good. There is a nice twist and it gives you some clues along the way. I can't say too much more without spoiling it.

The gameplay is very similar to other games like Baldur's Gate, but at a closer third person view and with a smaller party. Don't expect an open world, as areas are very small and closed off. In the late game you will find yourself wanting to stack your party with jedi with the heal and flurry abilities. Since you have little-to-no control over whether you hit, how you hit, or how you get hit, bosses end up being punching bags. They ignore your control abilities with saving throws and your heals can typically out-heal any damage they deal out. Your lightsabers also protect you well from blasters and other melee enemies die very quickly.

Characters are good. I thought I could romance a twi'lek who turned out to be 14. One is a conspiracy nut and a certain old man likes to use jedi mind tricks. For once, I actually liked getting involved with characters and knowing their backstory, whereas I am usually interested in the backstory of the world.

This game is a steal for $10. Graphics don't matter in this game. Gameplay holds up, but try to avoid min-maxing to avoid makign the game too easy. Try to roleplay a little with your party coomposition. Buy this game for the story and the characters. 8/10.

reviewText:
In all my 20 years of living. I have played everything from Super Mario RPG, all the way up to FarCry 4 and Fallout New Vegas, no game gives me a feeling, no, a sensation of feeling like a total badass like Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic. bonus points given due to it being made by Bioware.

Basic storyline: This game is set some 4,000 years before the original trilogy, during this time, the Sith are trying to take over the entire galaxy, just like your average bad guy corporation, after you spend thirty or so minutes of game time aboard a ship that should've been destroyed by the time you first opened your eyes, you already will have the basic controls down. After a few hours, you will get the force, despite this. I still tended to stick with the tried and true rifle-type weapons, even though the lightsabers, which come in dual, short and standard types, are incredible to look at and use,

RPG Elements: The greatest asset in this game, to me, is the ability to modify certain weapons and armour, including lightsabers and Jedi Robes that turn you into a walking laser sponge, the addition of a conversation system was one of the first examples I've seen, and was used later just as innovatively in the Mass Effect series.

Final thoughts: I love this game, it's light-hearted, but can be serious at the same time. I never had as much love for the second KoTOR game, because it didn't feel like the same game, if you're either a veteran of RPG's or are a kid just starting their journey into the gaming world, this is one of my personal top picks, it's fun, it can run on a potato, and for the hardcore Star Wars fan, it holds a little surprise from the comic series.

reviewText:
This is the best RPG of all time.

The mechanics are old, but work flawlessly, the story is incredibly modular, and at that, it's great, the characters are unique and interesting, and who wouldn't want to be a damn Sith Lord?

Essentially you and two others are the sole survivors of a ship that is attacked by the Sith. One of said survivors was a Jedi, and your mission is to find her on the planet from which you escape to. From their the story escalates and soon your a Jedi Knight with the decision of whether to follow the path of the dark side or to stay on the light. Your choices impact the outcome of the game.

reviewText:
Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is an Adventure RPG based on the D20 System. Set 4,000 years before the Galactic Empire, you are a Republic Soldier stuck in a war against a newly formed Sith Empire lead by former Jedi heroes, whose steps you retrace in an attempt to discover the source of their military power.

Pros: Nice story that explores the ages before the modern Star Wars setting, back when the Republic was half its size and most of the Galaxy was yet to be mapped. You are joined by a cast of up to 8 additional characters, up to 2 can join you at a time. You can travel to 5 different planets (with different environments, creatures to fight, and equipment to buy for you and your party). Different encounters or quests might unlock depending on which side character is in your party at a given time. Some items are upgradable standard enhancement parts, others are fully customizable such as lightsabers. Multiple side quests allow you to delve on which side of the force you want to be in. Oh, and the story has a great twist!

Cons: The graphics didn’t age too well, many objects and characters look very polygony. If you’re not familiar with tabletop RPGs and the D20 system, you can easily get confused of how the mechanics work when selecting weapons, upgrades and other equipment. Character creation is limited, at least by today’s standard, where you pick from a dozen pre-gen faces among 3 different classes to begin, then among 3 jedi classes. Each planet has a very linear map, with a few outbranching paths, again contrasting with today’s standards.

Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your list

If you’re not a fan of Star Wars, you probably won’t see the appeal of this game. Otherwise, it’s one of the best installments of the games. The game isn’t too lore-heavy, allows both light and hardcore fans to enjoy the settings and game. I recommend giving it a try, it’s worth the price!

—————————————————————————
This was just my opinion.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

reviewText: Where do you begin, when they ask you to review one of the best games of all time? It's hard, I tell you what. But I'll give it a shot, regardless.\n\nMy first experience with Knights of The Old Republic was on the original xbox, back in the year of 2004. And my only memories from it are good ones, walking on the bottom of the sea on the ocean world of Manaan, or wandering around amongst the trees of the wookie planet of Kashyyyk all made you feel incredible due to the great sound-design and beautiful (at the time) visuals. The gameplay can feel a bit slow and sluggish by todays standards since it's not superfast and pulse pounding the way some games are, but that's not what it was about, and frankly, I rarely cared so much about the gameplay in this title because of the fact that the story, the characters and the setting is what brings this puppy home. It's safe to say that what Bioware created with this title was a game of the ages, something that would stand the test of time forever, and proudly so. When people place this game on their Best games of all times" list
date: they do not do it for any other reason than the one that it is a god damn good game.\n\nThe story will take you far and wide

reviewText: This game was the 1st RPG game i have ever played i have spent countless hours on this game when it frist game out years ago on xbox it was ♥♥♥♥ing amazing then and it is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing now! This is truely my favorite game of all time!\nThe story is great with a awesome plot twist, Characters are really well voice acted. There are engaging chat options to choose from. The decisions you make have consequences good or bad. The whole feel of the game is very immersive you really feel like what you decide to play as. e.g  a Dark Jedi. The comabt system took me awhile to get use to but once you do you love it there are countless upgrades you can decide to pick for your character and party members i could go on and on about how great this game is but you really just have to experience it for yourself 10/10.\n

reviewText:
10 years ago this game was released to critical acclaim, winning multiple GOTY awards for obvious reasons to those that have played it. If you havent played it yet I strongly recommend you do as it is essentially your own Star wars trilogy. Ill go into why it is so in a spoiler section at the end but this game has such a great twist I wouldnt advise reading into it. But enough exposition and acclaim, The game feels like Star wars; From the fantastic sound design that captures the original score perfectly to the sound of lightsabers clashing and blasters firing. The set-peices, ships, weapons and armor all look like they are of some older era of the star wars universe capturing that feeling of an even longer time ago. The story and subject matter is (arguably) the best ever told and/or touched on in the Star wars universe telling countless stories of redemption, betrayal, revenge, hope, loss, sacrafice,ascension,downfall the list goes on, you become the embodiment of the character you play (good or evil) be it Sith, Jedi, Bounty hunter, Soldier, Scoundrel with any number intertwining for you to create this story thats set a long a fixed path into something of your own. Again making it your very own Star wars trilogy....

************************************SPOILERS************************************************************************************
From the point it begins to the point you escape Taris and arrive at the Jedi temple on Dantooine I consider to be the First Episode in th KOTOR trilogy and a story of the players new beginning (obviously). From the time you begin your training at the Jedi temple to the confronation and big reveal to be Episode II and the defining of the characters ascenion be it Dark or light. Events that Follow being Episode III with culmination of the Characters final acts as a savior and a Jedi or a Dark Lord of the sith.... Truly epic.

reviewText:
Set 4000 years before the Star Wars films, this has got it's own unique story about you. You decide how the game plays out, you choose what to say, you choose what to do and you choose a side. The Jedi or the Sith. The light side or the Dark.

There is so much to do, the main story is fun and long and there is so much side missions, from Bounties, character backstories, swoop races, gambling and more. My playthrough of this game lasted 30 hours.

One of the best things about this games has to be the characters and the story. You can save the universe or become the sith and seek to destroy it with a Jedi, a Chewbacca, an Assasin Droid, a Utility Droid, a Bounty Hunter and more by your side.

The combat was great, easy to use for RPG/Non RPG fans both, you have a huge invetory of weapons/armor to assign to your team, Blasters, Swords, Rifles etc.

You even get your own Light Saver which you can upgrade to make it extremely powerful, I went through the game with my powerful Duel Wielding Green Lightsavers and my Green Double Sided Lightsaver.

There is so much customization to let you know your in charge, you can unlock powers of the force, abilities, upgrade your teams stats, upgrade your racer and even your droids.

This is one of the best RPGs I have ever played and as a fan of the Star Wars films, I found this to be new and great fun.
I give it a rating of 10/10

reviewText: It's hard to find games like this. Its complexity. Its story. Its intrigue. Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic draws out as an instant role-playing game classic, influenced modern RPGs like never before. Developed by an unknown company, known as BioWare, the game is a golden hit by its original dialogue, choices, companions, and character development. The game even expands the Star Wars universe that can equate to the six Star Wars films by its popularity. Despite that the game was released in 2003, there is no argument that the game has a direct impact in popular culture and how it shapes other games, even Bethesda Studio's Elder Scrolls and Fallout series. Knights of the Old Republic is need to be played from anyone who thinks that other RPGs is better suit than this; they're wrong. Never underestimate the aged graphics and look upon its gameplay elements and choice elements that will determine your fate for the Star Wars galaxy.

If you're having major graphical glitches (but don't understand why because your computer isn't a chump,) turn off shadows and grass. I was enraged by not knowing this, but I hoped I helped someone out there! Thanks.
