reviewText:
This is my first playing a Bioware game ever and hearing the popularity of Bioware in recent years of its story and characters I had to check it out, and what better way they manage to create in their early works and my favorite franchise, Star wars!

Story
I will try sum it up as much possible without any major spoilers, the story is average good I’m sorry to say I can’t be wow by the plot which I will explain later in more details, but the main plot is interesting don’t get me wrong. The light vs. dark side I should say is cliché but there are some story telling that is pretty surprisingly interesting picking up half way through the game.

I chose to be light side because I’m always am and got motivated to defeat Malak the antagonist of the game. There are some nice moments where you go “awe” and “what” and that’s good, it shows Bioware was starting to stable themselves as the “capital ship” of 3rd party company.

However, their earliest isn’t much what I expected because the backstory of the old Republic never mention this ever and even talks about the origin of the war. Yes they do talk about the rise of the Sith but just a brief one, I was expected a prequel of the star wars movies about telling the origin of what happen about everything; the war, the rise of Sith, the origin of the Republic everything, but no not a whole lot and both side doesn’t show much color.

The Sith are so generic with their “I’m a snob so that means everyone I look is a weakling” their motivation of doing this to so weak to me, yes they do what Sith do but what they are doing just doesn’t convince me to show sympathy to them or even see them differently. Is just “he’s bad and we’re good.” What about the republic surely they are some goody-two shoes?

Well at first almost but no they can be somewhat corruptive and wrong of their morals too! And that’s what I want from it, the republic side showing its own “both side” but also want the Sith to show “their two faces as well” instead of all being rich snob Nazis.

A final note on this yes they do some moments with the Sith on Korriban but not entirely enough to see them as “they are evil but I can see their side point why they do this horrid things.”

Characters
the NPC and partners are interesting as well especially I like that when you got the time you can talk to them and hear some back stories even if you bring one of them along in one certain planet, more dialogue options to choose and you will have a good backstory of the character. Malak I think is a cool villain especially the way he talks plus and robo-jaw that he has is really cool to look at.

Now here comes the problems I have this game and two things are repetitive and cliché for the story aspect side. The NPC of any species just looks the same especially on the human side they have the same texture face model which doesn’t add a lot of emersion seing the same human character twice and even the voice, the alien sort of get a pass but their voice over just doesn't because they reuse the same alien language dialouge many times and it gets tired around the ears.

Yes, I know that Bioware was at their first steps and you could say is budget problem by not hiring more actors and having to change face textures about everything that won’t affect too much on the rating scale, is just a nitpick problem where you try to discover a new world with new species (though in my case I already know the species) but they sound the same you wanted to see many new variation looks/voice as possible. Hopefully in the second game when the game got very popular it will have more.


Choose your side
Alright now the big one and is, which side would you choose, well I should say, none of it matters! Well what I meant was it really doesn’t matter in “morality,” yes of course you still choose your light and dark ending but at endgame, for the rest of the game it really doesn’t matter if you are the lightest person in the world, you can still choose the dark path at the end of the game.

So what gives? What is the objective of those light side dark side points? Is really for gameplay wise in armor and weapons, the force powers I made my main character have some dark powers even some of my light-side partners, which doesn’t really matter if you are good or not you can still equip dark powers or light powers if you are choosing your endings. Another thing about the moral points is just cosmetic option but only in the dark path when your character begins to change color.

So now it sounds like it only effects gameplay and not story telling which blows badly right? Well at first yes, I thought it would be the biggest disappointment ever since no matter if you are the biggest jerk in this galaxy or the nicest one you can switch sides in matter of seconds. Well I should say not entirely in that center problem, because you can still have consequence when doing certain side quest and do evil things and in some planets some characters will pay you back hard, if you are prepare.

No, I think the big point taker has to be your partners’ reaction to the player’s action. Yes they say “you did a wrong thing” but they never “punish” you for it or better yet leave you or stop you even though they are the once that help you do the main’s dirty deed. Most of your partners are from the light side and whatever you do will make them react but not upon action which is really shame.

I expect during some quests or the main “dialogue” choice your friends will abandon you and you will be recruit with more dark players and the story switch to another quest, “conquest” I thought. You can be the biggest jerk without a reason to them and they won’t even leave your side no matter what you did, even by the next set of choice that you made “wrong” you can switch to being nice again and they will forget about your “dirty deeds.”

I find it odd that after everything I do bad they won’t bat an eye of my behavior which just tells me that my choice won’t affect much around me until the very end, but during the whole game experience I thought choosing one side might affect the story telling as two sides, one fight for the good or join the Sith and fight from the republic and you will eventually fight Yoda! (Which I know that isn’t him.)

My main when going dark or light doesn’t give a deeper meaning why he’s doing it, I’m just having that express feeling that “I do it because I’m a bully and want to take things just because,” “I’m good because I’m a goodie two-shoes,” and mind you I’m talking about story wise, the gameplay well that is different because I want the extra status boost.

The side missions some I like but is just another generic “do this because is the right thing to do and do this because you are a jerk” Even the options you choose sounds a bit preachy for me thinking “well duh of course is bad to do this but should I?” There is only one side quest I think is my favorite where it involve no light or dark side points and only pure morality choice which about there I got a moral dilemma and I wish there was more like that but I know if it is it makes the system even more pointless.

Verdict:
The final verdict is a 7/10 a good starting game for Bioware’s time but need improvement on the writing, and moral choice but other than that I did enjoy the game despite some minor flaws the gameplay works flawlessly and I don’t have much of a problem to say, hopefully when I finish star war kotor 2 maybe things will change and improve until then, may the force be with you.

reviewText:
Now, 12 years since its release, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic still stands as one of the finest games ever wrought by the hands of BioWare, long before they were corrupted by the Sith Lord Darth Riccitiello and turned to the dark side.

KotOR is a classic RPG with honest-to-god stats and skill points, an increasingly rare sight in these, the days of merciless streamlining. The graphics are obviously dated (but not an eyesore), and the combat finds a comfortable balance between simplicity and the necessity of pausing to issue commands to your party.

To fans of the Star Wars franchise, the world of the Old Republic will be familiar, but also incredibly alien. Unsurprisingly, the writing is clumsy by modern standards, equal parts railroading and patronizing handholding. You get the sense that each line of dialogue was written to leave an opening for every question you can ask, and characters have no problem imparting upon you the same piece of information a dozen times over the course of a conversation. In spite of this, however, the world makes it incredibly easy to immerse yourself in it.

Even with its shortcomings, KotOR is undeniably the genesis of the modern RPG, the proto-Mass Effect, and although you might not get it on with 100 year-old blue aliens, you can't help but feel that this is where it all began.

reviewText:
If you ever wondered where games like Mass Effect or Dragon Age came from, then sit down, my child, and let me tell you of a game called KOTOR.

This game is one of the best, all-time Western RPGs. Yeah, it's showing its age compared to more modern RPGs. Yeah, the combat system is clunky and easy to exploit (the AI's pathing is awful). Yeah, the graphics aren't the great thing they were back in the early 2000s. But the real heart of this game is the story and characters. It was one of the first games of its kind and wasn't afraid to take risks, paying homage to the old Star Wars trilogy while creating its own interesting universe and characters. I had this game as a kid on my old Dell (it was piece of junk) like ten years ago and I thought this game was the ♥♥♥♥ back then.

Basically, you play as a Jedi trying to stop the Sith from destroying the Republic. You can use the Force to bring unholy destruction on the dirty non-Jedi plebes or even just use blasters, because lightsabers are for the weak.

Generally, the choices go between being the nicest guy (or lady!) in the galaxy, or being a total ♥♥♥♥. But there's a lot of good writing you don't see in a lot of modern video games. Especially from your companions (9 of them in total).

I'm able to get it running on my MSI laptop w/Windows 10, so I'm not sure the difficulty others are having. I disabled movies and it works just fine (you're not missing out on anything essential with the movies). Also, get Flawless Widescreen from somewhere in the internets if you have a large monitor, it helps a bunch with some of the visual glitches users run into.

If this game comes on sale and you like Star Wars or RPGs, definitely consider buying it.

reviewText:
Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is one of the most beloved Star Wars games to date. It takes place about 4000 years before the Rebellion destroyed the first Death Star. The game is an RPG (Based on the D20 system, meaning the game 'rolls' to see how much damage you will do at the current turn). Before you start up, make sure to familiarize yourself with RPG mechanics (For example, you will want to know what Fortitude is, or saves)

The game has an average completion time of about 30 hours, and about 20 if you've played before. The story is one thing that is truly remarkable. If you haven't had the game spoiled for you, drop what you're doing and just invest your time into this, as it has one of the most compelling and unexpected stories you could find in the Star Wars universe.

Pros
-Long story
-Story keeps you invested
-Great variety of planets
-Lot's of variety in playstyles

Cons
-No native 1080p support
-Few bugs on newer OS's (Windows 7 and above)

reviewText:
I'm a huge Star Wars fan, so keep that in mind as you read this review.

I just played this game for the first time a couple weeks ago, and it was one of the most enjoyable experiences I've had in terms of gaming in a while. Despite this game being 13 years old it is much better than many games that have come out recently.

My favorite thing about Bioware games, whether it be Mass Effect, Dragon Age, or Knights of the Old Republic, is the characters that Bioware creates. I fell in love with every single character in this game. The interactions you can have with each character after every mission is great and something I always looked forward to while playing. I thought the romance with Bastila was well written and actually believable, unlike many other games. Also, as a huge fan of the Mass Effect series, it was so cool recognizing voice actors in this game, and they did a great job.

The plot in this game is well done in my opinion. I obviously won't go into specifics as I don't want to spoil anything, but the foreshadowing is great, and the plot twist is awesome.

Freaking lightsabers. The one thing I was looking forward to most coming into this game was crafting my first lightsaber, it wasn't all that great, but still pretty cool. Other than that, lightsabers are probably the coolest thing ever imagined and just being able to use one instantly makes this game awesome.

The combat in this game was something I was not used to and still don't like very much. I was coming into this game expecting to run around swinging my lightsaber randomly at enemies like you would in skyrim. However, this game has MMO type combat where you just click on enemies and the game takes care of the rest. I hated this at first but after a while I was ok with it.

Overall, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is a fantastic game, and my new most favorite. There are so many things done right in this video game. If you're a fan of Star Wars buy this game you will love it. If you're not a fan of Star Wars I still definitely recommend this game as it's one of the greatest of all time. I rate this game a 10/10.

reviewText: Oh my god, this game is awesome! At first, it kept crashing during cinematics, but running it in windowed mode will fix that. This game's quite old, so it's also harder: it doesn't autosave frequently and dying will force you to load a save up to 30 minutes ago (so always save!). If you get past these minor issues, the game's absolutely wonderful. It's increadibly immersive with great character development and story progression. It's nonlinear, so you can have a different experience everytime you play. I've only played through it once so far and I loved it. KOTOR's got a feature that's missing from a lot of todays games, but I can't really tell what that is. If you're a Star Wars fan, this is a must play!

reviewText:
I always had respect for the Star Wars franchise, wasn't a big fan boy (especially now that it was all bought out by Disney), but buying the Star Wars games on a whim from the HB store, (all but two games for $12) I had problems running KOTOR on my Windows 7 but I was surprised the game had GREAT content. It's not some throw away wannabe game from the movies I am used to seeing. (X-men, Spider-man, transformers) no, this game is it's own stand alone in the universe of Star Wars! I found it easy to get into and the story is promising to be a good one. When you have a library 300+ games and suffer from gaming OCD like I do, you find it hard for a game to keep your attention span for more then half an hour. But so far it's great and will recommend KOTOR to anyone.

You don't need to know the movies and books and stories by heart to be able to get right into the mix of things with KOTOR.

RPG fans will love it.

Turn Base fans will love it.

Can't wait to see how well KOTOR 2 is and the others of the franchise :)

Play it!

reviewText:
There is the reason why this game considered one of the best RPGs of all time. Made by Bioware long before they started soap opera by the name of Mass Effect, Star Wars: KotOR offers everything that PC Western RPG supposed to - non-linear structure, choices that affects game world, great, engaging story, and memorable characters. I am sure that I did not see everything this game has to offer, like ways of the Sith, or evens that will happen if you visit planets in different order.

Some things not aged that well, like lack of fast travel system between cleared of enemies’ areas or somewhat clunky interface. Made in 2003, KotOR does not support widescreen resolutions; however, this can be fixed with Flawless Widescreen.

Just buy this game and play it, it does not matter if you watched any of the Star Wars movies hence game takes place 4000 years before any of the movies.

Summarized: This game adds to the lore, plays very well, and brings you hours of pure entertainment for anyone. Even people who don't have the most knowledge about Star Wars could easily get into this game!

Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic is a game where it starts off slowly but as you delve into it the story will progress and you will shape the way your character is. To keep it short, there's actually choices that matter, even though the gameplay might not be as you'd like it still functions very properly and when we're talking about graphics, it is not the most beautiful game but it are enjoyable graphics to look at. The planets and locations you'll visit will keep you interested as it adds to the lore and true Star Wars fans will actually get to see new stuff!

The game is pretty cheap and I'd definitely recommend anyone who likes Star Wars to play it!

The sequel manages to develop this game's lead character in a more meaningful way, than the entirety of this game. The lead character of this game is barely in KOTOR2.

This game is alright

reviewText: KotOR is probably my favorite game of all time, for quite a few reasons. I remember picking it up back in 2003 when I was 8, just because it had 'Star Wars' in the title. Ever since then, I have played this game through numerous times. The game regardless of how you play it, is just plain fun. The graphics are dated, yet they still look pretty decent. The gameplay is challenging and rewarding. The setting and locations in this game are stunning. From the urban cities of Taris, the deserts of Tatooine, to the oceans of Manaan, all of the locations are beautifully done. The characters you meet are diverse and likable. Most are pretty interesting, including npcs. There are plenty of opportunities to walk around and explore or talk to characters off of the beaten path. There are also mini games such as Pazaak and swoop races. The story is intriguing and has many turns. It also has a lot of replayability. There are different conversation choices, different endings, different classes, abilities, weapons, character party, and for the hardcore players no alien subtitles. There are plenty of customization options for the weapons you use, whether you want to be a calm and thoughtful Jedi using lightsabers and the force, or be the smooth talking smuggler using blasters and grenades, you are able to choose the way you want to play.\n\nIn conclusion, this is probably my favorite game. It has decent graphics that have aged somewhat well. The locations, characters, and story are all well made and great. There are many options for customization and replayability. Also the game is just plain fun. I'd highly recommend it to any Star Wars, sci-fi, or rpg fan.

reviewText:
Seriously let me just be completely honest here. This game is amazing, but Can be a pain at times.
The game itself is absolutely amazing and it has a wonderful story that any starwars fan should be enthralled by.

HOWEVER! The fact remains that this game is extremely dated and it has a lot of problems when it comes to computers. It can be as I would put it whiny" and crashes a lot for some people. The game is so outdated that it literally thinks some pc parts are older than itself or it cannot recognize them.
I know many work around for this issue and they are on the forums
date: but it is still a pain.\nBeyond that
recommended: the graphics and some of the sounds are pretty iffy
hoursPlayed:
but since it is 10 years old you should expect that.

I would still recommend buying this game even if you wait for the steam summer/winter sales where it is 5-10 bucks. (US)
It is seriously worth it even after all of the problems behind it. (Be aware that the second is even worse off with those issues for some people.)"

reviewText: In this game you play Jar-Jar Binks, Sith Lord supreme. You travel the galaxy fighting a guy with so many cavities they had to amputate his jaw. Your companions include Kaiden and Commander Shepard in a rare crossover, a spunky teenager who isn't legal so you can't romance her even though this is a Bioware game and I fully expect everything to be romanceable; even the toaster, a Wookiee who's like Chewbacca but with suspenders instead of an awesome bandolier, a really really ugly catgirl, a wise old black dude, this old dude with a minigun, a robot that's like R2D2, and a robot that's like C3P0 except not British and gay. Along the way you learn that true strength lies within and also that even a developer who can't make two games in a row without retconning stuff can write better than George Lucas.

reviewText:
BUY IT!
NOW!

In my opinion the best Star Wars game ever made! Period!

The first time i played this game was right after it's release 2003 (?)
(Too lazy to look it up right now ^^).
Until today it's by far my favourite game from the Star Wars franchise
and still among my top 3 (if not the best) Singleplayer RPGs.

What distinguished it from the games i had played until that time was
the freedom to actively influence the story (WHICH IS AWESOME BTW!
This was made before Bioware learned the words DLC / Cliffhanger)
by my decisions, the depth and difficulty of the combat system
(especially on higher difficulty levels) coupled with a great party-system
as well as the the sheer content that is available
(you have to play this game at least twice (light side / dak side)
to get the full experience out of it, and you still will find new stuff with
every playthrough).

A warning though:
If you don't like turn based combat you might have trouble taking a liking to
this game. Even if the combat itself can be played in real-time and doesn't
pause by itself you will constantly die if you don't hit the pause-button
(which is the spacebar btw!) frequently on higher difficulties.

If you can get along with turn based combat, this game will offer the best
Star Wars experience anyone could hope for, including tactical depth,
awesome characters, and a story that is so well-told, no other game
until today was able to surpass it in that respect.

reviewText:
Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is a RPG any gamer can enjoy, a game that defined decision based conversation/character progression while employing real-time turn based combat and a story that will pull you in from the moment it begins, KOTOR is a game everyone should try at some point.

Based around the time of the dark lords Revan & Malak and The Old Republic you will embark on a journey faced up against the might of the Sith Empire.
Every companion has their own story and full length conversations throughout the game some will even grab the hearts of many fans just as much as the story does.

reviewText:
I tend not to play RPGs or at least keep a distance or ignore them in any way possible. They are out of my comfort zone and I can do nothing about it,  I'm too scared, too frightened to fire it up and it is especially hard for me to start such a long journey and commit myself to +40h of story. But at the same time I adore RPGs, I love them with all my heart and I love that they make me feel the way they do.

I was thinking about playing KOTOR but I never had a chance to. I heard a lot of positive responses over the years of its existence so I got it on Steam Sale. This is one of the most prominent representatives of RPG genre with great story telling, one of the most unexpected plot twists I've ever seen implemented in a video game, 6 different planets for you to explore filled with side quests, loot, lightsabers and other shenanigans for you to find. It features excellent character skill tree and d20 roll" system (named after the iconic 20-sided dice) which seems the most honest one.
"

reviewText:
One of the best Star Wars games of all time...



What? You want me to explain? Fine. A traditional Star Wars story that captures the heart and soul of the series and is 10 times better than anything Lucas has written since Return of the Jedi. Set a couple 1000 years before Phantom Menace (Lucas wouldn't let them get any further away from it), Bioware was given the creative freedom to write their own narrative, succeeding in creating not just one of the greatest Star Wars games ever made (arguably the greatest, behind a heavily modded KOTOR 2) but one of the greatest Star Wars stories ever told. Helping you on your adventure is a cast of colorful Bioware characters that you'll either love (Bastila) or hate (Carth) but find engaging nonetheless. Possessing classic real time combat that doesn't feel as dated as it should for game that is 12 years old, newcomers will be able to adapt its to Pre-Skyrim style quite easily. Engaging voice acting from some of the best (Jennifer Hale and Kevin Michael Richardson to name a few) just seals the deal. The visuals are a little dated but that just means any modern computer can play this game at full settings. Besides, presentation is everything and Bioware's models are just as Star Wars as the movies.

reviewText: This game has it all:  Massive, extensive plot, 4(+) worlds to explore, a well-made lightside/darkside system, hundreds of quests, more weapons than you could ever need, customizable weapons, customizable characters, awesome combat (Real time, but you can pause at anytime:  this is very important and USEFUL) and 9 likeable and very real partymembers, each with there own extensive backstory and quest. You never play the same way twice.  10/10 would play again (and again, and again...)

reviewText: Set thousands of years before Luke Skywalker leaves Tatooine, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic sets you into a galaxy that is familiar, yet new and exciting at the same time. KOTOR is truly one of the best, if not the best, titles BioWare has put out. In fact, it is one of the best RPGs  on the market, and, needless to say, this a game that EVERY self respecting Star Wars fan needs to play. The characters are compelling, and the storyline is one of the best game storylines I have ever played. Even after all the years it has been out, the game still holds up as fun and enjoyable, and still gets multiple playthroughs from me. I cannot speak highly enough about this game. For anybody who wants a gripping and epic Star Wars storyline, this game should be at the top of your list to play.

5/10

reviewText:
Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic. When this game released many moons ago I was a young teenager. I have never played an RPG before and even worse: I did not know this game was an RPG. Unaware of my ignorance I placed the game into the the disc tray of my Xbox and never looked back. Since the release of the game I have over 1000 hours of play time between the Xbox and PC version. But what makes this game so good?

Firstly is the the story. From the first second you feel a level of immersion that I find hard to get with other games. What makes the story even more enjoyable is that each playthrough you can do things differently and experience something new.

Character customization has almost everything I could want in a game. While there are restrictions with physical appearance in character creation everything else seems to disregard it. The leveling system is beautiful with enough options that ensure every character you create will be different if you try. I find myself being immersed with the Equip screen as well, sometimes going through my equipment just to see what I will look in various armors/robes.

The gameplay itself is satisfying. Using a real time turn based combat system, you rarely feel things are moving slow. While in combat you have the ability to pause the game, if you wish, and issue up four commands for your companions to perform. Experimenting with this can be fun to see what type of damage you can do and how quickly you can kill harder opponents.

Overall, I would highly recommend this game for any Star Wars or RPG fan. Knights of the Old Republic is a milestone in gaming and everyone should try to experience what it hast to offer.

reviewText:
Years later and this game is still a fun, challenging game with such a great atmosphere. The world created for this era predating even the prequel movies by thousands of years is fantastic, for Star Wars fans and RPG fans alike. The characters are memorable, the cinematic moments in the game keep you on the edge of your seat, and the game play is interesting.

In terms of gameplay, this is probably the closest thing to a virtual, 3D version of Dungeons & Dragons I've ever played. It's based on a very similar stat/skill/feat system, with rolls calculated by your computer deciding how combat plays out. If that kind of strategic, min-max type of gameplay appeals to you, then this game is a great choice.

Partly for nostalgia, but mostly because of the immense amount of love and care that Bioware put into KOTOR, it remains my favourite game of all time.

reviewText: A game coming from the good days of Bioware, with a deep setting, and a shapeshifting plot. The story is riddled with plot twists, and the game is using a form of D&D in combat, so the D20 still reigns supreme. The visuals fare just fine, and the music is well-placed in the various locations of the game. Sure, there are a few occasional bugs, and some can be quite annoying, which, when combined with the game's above-average combat difficulty, can cause some headaches. But the drawbacks are largely overshadowed by the well-done aspects of the game. If you're a fan of the Star Wars universe or not is unimportant, since an excellent RPG is the same, no matter the setting. Buy it and do the old Bioware justice.

reviewText:
Pretty cool game. I didn't get to play this game around the time it came out so the graphics are a bit dated for me. But the rpg elements are nice, you get to customize your stats (like str, dex, int, etc.), skills (like opening doors, repairing droids, etc.), and feats (which are actions you can do in combat or passives that gives bonus). If you don't want to do all that customizing, you can just auto allocate them in the options. Some items, like armour, lightsabers, and other weapons, are customizable that will increase damage or add effects like a chance to stun your enemy.

The story, which is probably why you're here, is pretty good. Side missions are good. You get to choose your conversations when interacting with npcs, some of them can make a difference in the story while others doesn't. Just a warning though, there is a lot of talking in this game and if you try to choose every possible conversation, some of the npcs will just repeat the same information that you got from other npcs.

Overall, this ♥♥♥♥ is good. If you're an rpg fan and doesn't mind dated graphics and long conversations, this ♥♥♥♥♥ is for you. I give this game a thumbs up, as you can see up top.

reviewText: Ah, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic, this game carries many of my life's memories (since when it was released in Australia I was 5). Several days later, I went from school to a friend's house, Akko (who you can find on my friends list). Akko had KotOR on his Xbox, we started playing it, that was when I realised, that it wasn't some werid game that we couldn't figure out how to play, we just didn't give it a chance!!! Sorry if this story bored you! But yeah, this game has to be THE BEST, Star Wars game every created, I recommend buying it, and tell all your friends!!\n\nAlso check out my YouTube Channel where I do KotOR Walkthroughs and the like! https://www.youtube.com/user/NinkoKotOR

reviewText:
I played through this game, it's storyline is rich and creative and backed up by some brilliant voice acting and graphics especially for a 2003 game. I will not spoil the story but it has an excellent ending and interesting plot twists which the user will not expect. It is a fantastic chapter in the Star Wars universe and I highly recommend it to any RPG fans as it truly makes the genre hard to better, again for a 12 year old game it is unbelievably addicting and will have you playing the game non-stop until you finish.

It has replayable value as you get to choose your own path, light side or dark side you have the choice entirely and conversational structure in the game allows you to make these decisions.

Puzzles feature heavily throughout the game and are challenging with little aid, personally I struggled with them and had to research how to solve them online but they can be easily figured out with some effort. The characters in this game are unique and loveable, they aid the protagonist throughout and help influence your decisions if you allow yourself to fall into this game's smart trap of wanting to make your companions happy so you make decisions based on their interests.

Overall I would put this game into my top 5 list of games ever, and it easily has one of the best storylines of any game I've encountered as an RPG fan.

reviewText:
Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic is a third person rpg set 4000 years before the events of the first movie. It starts off with you being able to customize your character to be either male of female and choosing your class. Afterwards you get into the actual game as your ship is immediately being attacked and boarded by the Sith. You are quickly overwhelmed and crash land on the starting planet. The planets and environments are one of the best features to the game. They are all very unique and offer lots of room to explore. You can converse with most alien species since your character speaks nearly every language under the Republic's domain. Some speak in their native tongues and you understand via subtitles but man do they talk slow. It could take upwards to 20 seconds for every sentence as they grumble and grunt their language at you which made me very glad there is an option to skip sentences with the click of the mouse. It's usually worth talking to them as they explain their culture, problems and feelings on the war between the Republic and the Sith.

Your companions on the other hand are some of the most annoying and broody bunch of support characters I've ever seen. Don't get me wrong a few are actually really cool but it would be nice to kick most of them out of your base. You can take up to two of them with you on missions and you can equip and dress them however you like. They will sometimes trade quips or add their opinions into a conversation which helps flesh them out more. An alignment system is in place where you can either focus on the light side by doing good deeds or the dark side by evil ones. It's not just a superficial system, being on the light sides makes casting dark side powers a lot more difficult for you to cast. You can also be neutral but it is pretty hard to maintain. Which makes for a lot of interesting circumstances on whether you want to help someone due to being dangerously close to steering toward the light side which has nowhere near the strength of the dark side powers. We don't start of as a jedi and don't have these powers at the start of the game but it is something to keep in mind.

Gameplay consists of auto-attacking and clicking on abilities to either damage or heal. There is an option to pause time and set commands to each of the party members which lets you use plan your battles far easier than trying in real time. At times your character will just freeze up and not do anything while enemies get free shots in. Happens rarely but is infuriating when it happens in a brutal fight. A glitch that happens a lot more occasionally is being unable to move after a battle. It fixes itself after 30 seconds of not doing anything but with the amount of battles in this becomes a real problem. Activating Vsync fixes this problem for some people. You can use a shield a limited amount of times, throw grenades, lay land mines and use force powers which makes for a lot of variety. Never gets old seeing a  Jedi get fed up with fighting a group of enemies and just throws a grenade.  Melee combat is pretty cool as well, they have a preset fighting animations where they kick, dodge and slash at each other. You have no control over it but it definitely adds more action to the fights. Ranged has a single animation where you dodge some blaster rounds but starting off your aim is so bad that it would make a StormTrooper blush.

Outside of combat you can explore, disarm landmines and pick locks considering you have the skill to do so. You can gamble in some kind of modified version of BlackJack but you need to collect the cards of the deck yourself. You can also join Swoop races that play like your modern day runner. There are also turret sections on occasion where you can defend your ship from an attack fleet. On top of all that there are a ton of side quests and having done nothing but what I was required to I still got 31 hours out of the game so as you can see it is a very lengthy game. Most of the time you will be in dialogue with another character and given multiple ways to answer or deal with dilemmas. Unfortunately the voice acting ranges from mediocre to terrible and considering the amount of talking you do it may be a bit of a turn off to some. That is the only thing wrong with the sound side of things. The music has a mix of original Star Wars music and some newly composed music that all sound excellent. The sound of blasters, electrocuting people and lightsaber fights all sound great as well.

Story is kind of dull. It starts off promising but quickly devolves into a treasure hunt for maps.  Occasionally you will get a cut-scene of the villain sending some useless goons to hunt you to remind the player he even exists. The story really picks up near the end of the game though. You'll mostly be interested in the politics of each planet and the troubles they are going through like trying to stay neutral in the war, slavery and criminals controlling everything. Your choices have some pretty big impacts like medicine costing much more credits (money) to everyone, yourself included. It is definitely the type of game you play for the adventure instead of the grand overall plot.  Graphics are obviously dated with character models looking very ancient but the environments themselves look decent.  The menus are awful. You can pick up as much stuff as you want without limits but everything in the inventory is seemingly placed at random,without ways to quickly reach a category of weapon or to sell junk it really becomes a chore. You will have to change weapons since some are much more efficient against certain types of enemies and would have been made so much less frustrating by a decent menu.

It is a good game don't get me wrong but it is not the greatest rpg ever that some people claim it to be. I had quite a bit of fun with it and will immediately play the sequel after this review. I am not a Star Wars fan though so that may be a fact to take into consideration.  Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic is a fun game dragged down by some technical and  user interface issues but still manages to be a game worth considering if you are into the genre.It's also nice to see a Star Wars game not including Obi Wan or Luke like most games and you can tell they put a lot of effort into weaving their own identity into the Star Wars universe. It still holds up against the rpgs of today and shouldn't be dismissed due to it's age.

reviewText:
this is my first review so it will probably suck but this game deserves it. this game is easily one of the top 5 games i ever played i had 2 playthroughs on the original xbox and thanks to the humble bundle got this and alot of other starwars games for an extremely good deal. currently working on my third playthrough right now and am only 2 planets through, i fully completed taris and just have to return the mandalorian girl to finish dantooine. i never knew about the yavin space station on the xbox i have no idea if it is pc exclusive either since my swkotor mysteriously went missing >.>  the space station was amazing for getting powerful gear and pazaak games are very fun to me, especially when f4 and f5 can help me farm cash from the npc's to get my spent cash back. just from all of this i have 20.7 hours logged, never went to manaan,koriban,kashyyk or tantooine. amazing game filled to the brim with life and quests.
+backround dice rolls for combat is extremely good
+tons of quests to do with possibly days of content
+variety of things to kill
+tons of places to go from underwater military outposts to space stations to wide plains of either farmland or desert.
+pazaak and racing minigames are fun and easy ways to get cash
-very buggy for me im on a windows 7 when i play on the pc but half the time i get out of combat my characters are stuck and i either have to quicksave quickload or switch characters or run around for awhile, holding w and d or a for a few revolutions tends to fix it as well, also once on taris the npc glitched and i was stuck in dialogue for 2 minutes until he popped into existence again.
-i miss over half of my attacks -.- seriously i nearly died fighting the guy in charge of the vulcars but bastila saved me, and yes i realise upping the strength of whatever will up my chance to hit but i spend it all on persuade.
-some people here are complaining about the camera angles but i dont have to much problems with it.
-inventory is definitly messed up but switching to what your looking for (like quest items or new items) will help alot.
- the ai sometimes takes a minute to catch up to you making you wait at a door for awhile.
-bad graphics for 2015 standards but this was a game from 2003 i think? for such a massive game and with its considerable age the graphics are amazing

in all this game is amazing and definitly deserves to be called a classic this and battlefront 2 are probably my favorite games ever (never played swkotor2 yet but i heard it's extremely buggy).
a few tips for beginners get force persuade quickly it is amazing, also on the yavin space station buy anything you want and f4,f5 when you play him in pazaak if you want to get all of your cash back to keep on spending, even make a profit off of it.

reviewText: KotOR is a traditional RPG that was released in 2003. I played it for the first time in 2011 and found the graphics and gameplay to be very playable. reviewText:
Despite being over a decade old, the game still maintains a modern feel. I have been getting some issues with character getting stuck on the spot and not moving unless you can investigate a nearby item or switch character.

The story is consistent and there is a huge level of dialogue available, each character has their own story, but also depending on who is in the party will talk to each other about different subjects. This can be a little random on occasion to be walking in a sewers killing Rakghouls to then have the game paused because Misson looks 'distant'.

Still love this game, still poses some challenges in early game play and offers a solid RPG experience.

reviewText:
The best Star Wars licence game ever made and one of the best RPG games of all time. Period.

There's little to be said about this masterpiece. Even being a 12 year old game, it didn't age badly and still plays fantastically. Possible to launch it in 1080p with a bit of tinkering. Game is fairly unstable on modern OS and in one playthrough crashed about 7 or 8 times. Still, all technical negatives aside the game still feels wonderfully crafted. Endless dialogs, various quests, different and varied locations and choices with serious consequences - all these elements are only a small part of the whole KOTOR package. HK-47 is probably one of the best video characters BioWare has ever made, or even in general.

Game does have it's flaws. For example: inventory system is really basic and once you start hitting 20-30+ hours into the game, and if you're a hoarder, it gets very difficult to find stuff that you need, since everything is thrown into one pile. Camera can take some getting used to, but overall won't be too much of a trouble. AI pathing is poor, ofter will your AI partners get stuck and you'll have to take control of them to make them move towards you again. Also your AI doesn't use health packs, stimulants, or any other consumable, half the time they don't even use their learned abilities. There is a Script" option
hoursPlayed: and it only offers 3 rudimentary options.\n\nSome of the above mentioned negatives are more or less nitpicks

votesTotal: but I personally did not find it too difficult to setup fights with my party
votesFunny: while also controlling my own character. Game does have a pause

reviewText:
Pretty cool game. I didn't get to play this game around the time it came out so the graphics are a bit dated for me. But the rpg elements are nice, you get to customize your stats (like str, dex, int, etc.), skills (like opening doors, repairing droids, etc.), and feats (which are actions you can do in combat or passives that gives bonus). If you don't want to do all that customizing, you can just auto allocate them in the options. Some items, like armour, lightsabers, and other weapons, are customizable that will increase damage or add effects like a chance to stun your enemy.

The story, which is probably why you're here, is pretty good. Side missions are good. You get to choose your conversations when interacting with npcs, some of them can make a difference in the story while others doesn't. Just a warning though, there is a lot of talking in this game and if you try to choose every possible conversation, some of the npcs will just repeat the same information that you got from other npcs.

Overall, this ♥♥♥♥ is good. If you're an rpg fan and doesn't mind dated graphics and long conversations, this ♥♥♥♥♥ is for you. I give this game a thumbs up, as you can see up top.

The story in this game is by far the best writing by Bioware in my opinion. Especially the epic plot twist about your character when confronting Darth Malak, this game's Dark Lord of the Sith. reviewText:
this is my first review so it will probably suck but this game deserves it. this game is easily one of the top 5 games i ever played i had 2 playthroughs on the original xbox and thanks to the humble bundle got this and alot of other starwars games for an extremely good deal. currently working on my third playthrough right now and am only 2 planets through, i fully completed taris and just have to return the mandalorian girl to finish dantooine. i never knew about the yavin space station on the xbox i have no idea if it is pc exclusive either since my swkotor mysteriously went missing >.>  the space station was amazing for getting powerful gear and pazaak games are very fun to me, especially when f4 and f5 can help me farm cash from the npc's to get my spent cash back. just from all of this i have 20.7 hours logged, never went to manaan,koriban,kashyyk or tantooine. amazing game filled to the brim with life and quests.
+backround dice rolls for combat is extremely good
+tons of quests to do with possibly days of content
+variety of things to kill
+tons of places to go from underwater military outposts to space stations to wide plains of either farmland or desert.
+pazaak and racing minigames are fun and easy ways to get cash
-very buggy for me im on a windows 7 when i play on the pc but half the time i get out of combat my characters are stuck and i either have to quicksave quickload or switch characters or run around for awhile, holding w and d or a for a few revolutions tends to fix it as well, also once on taris the npc glitched and i was stuck in dialogue for 2 minutes until he popped into existence again.
-i miss over half of my attacks -.- seriously i nearly died fighting the guy in charge of the vulcars but bastila saved me, and yes i realise upping the strength of whatever will up my chance to hit but i spend it all on persuade.
-some people here are complaining about the camera angles but i dont have to much problems with it.
-inventory is definitly messed up but switching to what your looking for (like quest items or new items) will help alot.
- the ai sometimes takes a minute to catch up to you making you wait at a door for awhile.
-bad graphics for 2015 standards but this was a game from 2003 i think? for such a massive game and with its considerable age the graphics are amazing

in all this game is amazing and definitly deserves to be called a classic this and battlefront 2 are probably my favorite games ever (never played swkotor2 yet but i heard it's extremely buggy).
a few tips for beginners get force persuade quickly it is amazing, also on the yavin space station buy anything you want and f4,f5 when you play him in pazaak if you want to get all of your cash back to keep on spending, even make a profit off of it.

reviewText:
In my humle opinion, one of the best RPG's and certainly one of the best Star Wars games ever to grace this world.

I honestly can't find any flaws in this game (apart from the dated graphics, but that is of no concern).
If you ever had a dream of being a brutal Sith, slashing your way through varied enemies, or being a noble Jedi, inspiring his followers and dealing out justice, then this is the game for you.
There are a lot of  replayability in this game, and the sequel, and in almost every playthrough, you will discover something new (especially if you start toying around with mods), whether it be new dialogue, new items, another way to do a mission etc, and it is just so satisfying.

All in all, if you are a fan of well-done RPG's or Star Wars, this is an absolute must.

reviewText:
Hands down, one of the best RPGs available for PC or Mac. Bioware (already renown for Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights) took the Star Wars universe and did it justice; proving it could make for a damn fine game. Whether you're a Star Wars fan or just a fan of the RPG genre, KOTOR is every bit worth owning.

PROS:
+Good amount of customization for protagonist and team members.
+Choice between Light Side and Dark Side with every decision made within the story.
+Huge, open-world exploration spanning multiple planets.
+Non-linear story; both in terms of moral choices and the effects of some side missions.
+Some cool mini-games, from Swoop racing to Pazaak (card game).
+Endless REPLAY VALUE.

CONS:
-6th gen (PS2 era) graphics will annoy graphics snobs.
-No multiplayer.
-No Steam Achievements (yet).
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is a fantastic game.  I have played a lot of Star Wars and this one is easily my favourite one.  The subtle choices that have are posed to the player (male or female) generate Light or Dark Side points which affect how the NPCs react to your character.  The level up system is very customizable, allowing you to craft your character in whichever way you see fit.  The story is very engaging and left me wanting more from each of the characters.  The Pros and Cons list that follows are just general points; it must be said that not having a controller does not detract from the gameplay at all.  It is, in fact, one of the games that got me out of the need to have a controller to play games.

Pros:
-	Great story
-	Excellent combat
-	Well written characters
-	Exploration

Cons:
-	No widescreen support or un-stretched full screen
-	Visually, not a lot of character customization
-	No controller support
-	Graphics can be glitchy at times

All in all, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is a wonderful experience that has a lot of replay value.

reviewText:
If only Steam counted the hours I have on console.

Where do I start?

This was made back in the day when Bioware could do no wrong.  When they were the kings of storytelling.

It's really hard to write a decent review without spoiling this game for someone who hasn't beat it.

Turn-based, combat roll rpg.

On PC, the contols are ♥♥♥♥♥.
But don't let that stop you.  This is one of the greatest stories ever told in gaming.  One that has stood the test of time, been expanded, borrow, fanified, cosplayed and loved by many.

Perhaps I am looking at this game through rose colored glasses, because I can't remember the bad things about it.

The planets you go to, the characters you talk to, the lies, the arguments, the sacrifices for the greater good.
If you love Star Wars, you should already own this.  I do.  Twice.

reviewText:
This is quite literally one of the greatest games to ever grace the gaming world!

When I played this game for the first time I was immediately drawn into the story and was surprised and thrilled throughout this grand journey. The story, in my opinion, is the best of any RPG to date with interesting characters and satisfying plot lines throughout the game.
The plot unfolds in a clear and logical direction and keeps you engaged. There are several worlds to explore, each with unique environment and challenges. The character leveling is fairly simple and provides a multitude of options for you to build your character to fit your playstyle. Quests are rewarding and can be completed how you see fit, each with its own consequence, big or small. The tutorials are helpful and will get new players moving along right from the start. The combat system is easy to understand and works very well both automatically and for a strategic and keen minded player. The inventory is very easy to manage and understand, and there is never a shortage of options when it comes to buying or using items.
Although this game was released over a decade ago, it remains one of my all-time favorites, as well as my favorite RPG. It has stood the test of time as it still looks very nice and smooth, (even on the Xbox version), functions exceptionally well, and continues to keep players engaged and captivate their interest to this day. This is a must-have for any Star Wars fan! If you are a gamer who enjoys an exciting and rewarding narrative wrapped up in a masterfully designed system of combat and dialogue than this is the perfect game for you!	10/10 ***** A+ 100%

A true masterpiece!

reviewText: As the Game of the Year in 2003 for a multitude of publications and standing the last twelve years as one of the most highly-regarded games ever within the Star Wars universe, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is an RPG experience that, quite frankly, you'd be a fool to miss out on. Featuring a combat system based more on Dungeons and Dragons than the action-based Mass Effect or Skyrim, the round-based combat effectively delivers on the lightsaber and blaster battles anyone who loves the films craves, while offering a unique and captivating storyline set in its own special corner of Star Wars.\n\nIf I'd impart one piece of advice before sending you off to purchase what is admittedly one of my favorite games of all time, it would be this: Persevere. Do not let Taris intimidate you, and for goodness sake, savor the few hours before you delve into the flash and hum of lightsabers and Force Powers to get to know the place. Quite frankly, this is one of the most in-depth and immersive games out there, especially from Bioware, and woe be to the gamer who sees the dice roll mechanics and whines because he can't aim down a scope or he has to listen to actual character. This is an RPG, and a fine one at that. Give it time, and it will give you a phenomenal experience.

reviewText: I decided to revisit old RPGs which i had missed out on at the time, and let me say this game was completely worth it. I would recomend it to any rpg gamers out there unless you hate the star wars series with a passion. Unlike what i find in many modern RPGs this game is not linear, you can chose where to go when you want and not simply made to for the story (Although certain plot points will restrict this for a time). The game reminded alot of Mass Efeect 1 in the way it ran which would probably be expected as both are from Bioware. The cast of characters were interesting though some seemed to lack in any real development. The free rein to play in which ever style you want complements the gameplay, if you dont want to be a jedi  you can still use blasters and vaporise those who satnd in your way. The only major bug i came acrss in my experience is that randomly after combat some characters would not be able to move which did get irritating at parts where the player has control over an individual character instead of the three man party so if this glith is experienced save regualy. Despite some of its criticisms this is a great game and if your a fan of RPGs this will have you hooked. 9.3/10

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by my Steam playtime. This was the RPG that got me into RPGs (narrowly beating out Morrowind) and when I was young I played through the game in every single way possible on my Xbox. Best birthday gift my grandmother ever gave me.

If you enjoy any RPG or story rich games, this is an old gem from the 6th generation that is worth revisiting, even if the graphics don't hold up anymore. The story is amazing, to say the least, and shot Bioware to fame; without KOTOR who knows if they would have made Dragon Age or Mass Effect? If you like those two latter titles, KOTOR is clearly the blueprint of success that Bioware has been building upon in all of their other titles.

It is sad that KOTOR II was sent off to Obsidian and that the MMORPG they made have failed to reach the original game's stature, but it is a very large shadow to fill.

Bastila and Carth, Malak and Revan -- the characters are very well developed and the voiceacting is still great (and especially for the time period the game is from).

The game is so good I bought it on Steam just so I could review it. Give it a shot and you won't regret it.

Still love this game, still poses some challenges in early game play and offers a solid RPG experience.

The fact that it was developed in 2003 is redundant, once you realize that enshrined within this game is what atmosphere, story depth, character progression, and gameplay should be like in more games. reviewText:
This is my number one game of all time, and I definitely don't say that lightly. I may not have a huge amount of hours on this, but that's only because I played this so much before it was on Steam. It's not perfect, but then no game is without faults. I love everything about the Star Wars expanded universe and this is the pinnacle of it, it rises high above the waste and filth that are 90% of Star Wars video games and stands proudly as an amazing story drive experience. Light Side or Dark side, you choose, it's all up to you and it will affect you're ending and which of your party members decide to stand with you.

I'm not normally a fan of turn based combat, but they nailed it right here, the animations, the visuals and the effects
do look quite dated now but believe me, at the time it was a sight to behold.

It's hard to give this a neutral critical review because it would be like insulting my child if I were to say too many negative things against it. I cannot recommend this game enough. BUY IT WHATEVER THE PRICE

Plus it has one of my favourite WTF moments in gaming.

reviewText:
What can i say? This game is absolutely amazing from start to finish.
The plot is very strong with some suprising twists which makes it interesting as well.
The characters that follow you have their own background, and your companions may trigger an argument making it feel more alive!
The combat is turn-based and easy to understand, with the ability to pause in the middle of the battle, giving you time to set up a strategy.
Throughout the game, your actions will change who you are alligned with, whether its the dark side or the light, each having their own unique powers giving it some replayability.
There are many side quests for you to complete ranging from interrogating to finding missing holocrons, adding a bit of variety.
The only downsides that i give to this game are: the autosave sucks a lot, so make sure you save often to avoid any stress.
The AI sometimes messes up, whether they block your way, they get stuck and rarely stop attacking and bugs out for a second or two.

Overall i give this game a 9.5/10 because it is one of the best star wars games of all time. It has a lot of content for you to explore and learn the universe of star wars, i believe if you can bypass these cons, this game is a perfect 10/10 without a doubt.

reviewText:
This game has been around for quite a few years now. It is one of the best RPG's out there, along with it's sequel, and hands down a must-play if you are a Star Wars fan!

Currently, the movement can be a bit buggy. I don't recall this as an issue when I played it back on Windows XP years ago, but simply switching to one of your other controllable characters allows the other character to move out of the terrain glitch. I have only had the very rare crash so far in 20 hours of gameplay (I think twice). This game has a decent story, and plenty of weaponry to choose from. It allows both melee and ranged (blaster/bowcaster) gameplay, and the combat is turn-based in real-time, while still pausable at any time in the game to allow control of your characters and their combat options. There are times when you might come across a group of enemies to eliminate, during which your first attempt might end in complete failure, and minimal losses to the enemy; whereby approaching with a different strategy / different abilities, you may not lose a single companion, and find the fight much easier. Such is the combat mechanic depth.
Graphics I can't say much about due to it's age, but they are good enough on the Steam version of this game to at least scale somewhat to to a widescreen configuration. In other words, the game is very playable (albeit not with the graphical content or depth of, say, Assasin's Creed).

Absolute 10/10

And if you enjoy this game and it's playstyle, then absolutely recommended is the sequel!!!! Happy Gaming!

reviewText: This game is incredible. While it is an old game (2003), with not very impressive graphics, it boasts an incredible story, with side quests at every turn. You begin on the Endar Spire, a Republic Star Ship, which has been taken over by Sith. You, and a Republic pilot Carth, are the only survivors. You crashland in your escape pod on the planet Taris. What I find incredible about this is that it has it's own original storyline. While it has details that are the same (like Wookies and over races) it adapts them to make you have an enjoyable time while playing. I would highly recommend this game to just about anyone!\nIt is a fully singleplayer game, however it's sequel Knights of the Old Republic 2, does have a multiplayer mode. I've only played three hours, and haveb't gotten very far into the story. Just, buy it. It's only $3.00 in the winter sale. I can guarantee that you won't be disapointed (except when there is a supposed hacker attack on Steam, and you can't acess KOTOR. That is the only time you can get understandably ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about the game)\nA shout out to Potato Retrieving Master, who persuaded me to buy it. Thank you!

reviewText: Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is an amazing game that truly takes my breath away. I played it not very long ago, after missing out on this beautiful masterpiece of a game. reviewText:
Just finished this game for the 1st time after seeing that it was $2.99 on the Steam Holiday sale, & it's by far one of my top 5 RPG games of all time.

Pros:
I love how vast the Star Wars KOTOR universe is (especially for such an old game) & how the player can steer the game in any direction that they choose since there are so many ways the game can be played.

Also, the character customization is great & the story is very solid & immersive. If you're a fan of Star Wars & love RPG-type games such as the Witcher series, then I highly recommend this game.

Cons:
In my opinion, the ending/s of the game was a little weak. It was very short, abrupt, & unsatisfying after playing through such a deep & immersive story to say the least.

Also, once you finish the story, you can no longer free roam. Instead it takes you back to the main menu where your only options are to reload previous saves or start a new game. I wasn't a fan of this since I spent so much time upgrading my character & making him look cool just to find out that you literallty can't do anything with him after completing the story.

Still an amazing game though! Highly recommend.

reviewText:
Spent all my time negging Mission and Bastila while they fought over me.

10/10 would neg again.

Jk (sort of). In all seriousness though. this has to be one of the greatest games ever made, a fact most major gaming publications have agreed upon. I played it many years ago, but never finished. Now I've returned to the KOTOR universe, and I can't see myself not finishing it this time around.

The gameplay is very strategic and smart. It's addictive no matter your success rate. When you dominate in combat, you want to continue dominating. When you fail, success usually seems so close that you want to try again until you've won. The same can be said of the mini-games... I've put way more time into Pazaak than I care to admit.

However, it's the character development where the game really shines. The slow build towards making significant changes in the Star Wars universe captures the tone and feel of A New Hope way better than most other Staw Wars tie-ins. Most of the voice acting is incredibly strong and reasonably paced. It was actually a pleasure to listen to the voice work, which is a must in a game with this much dialogue.

With a little elbow grease (digitally speaking, of course) you can mod your way to a truly incredible experience. Some of the hi-res textures out there really help modernize the title. There are many, many other gameplay enhancements to be downloaded too, although I've been trying to keep my experience as close to the original as possible.

To that point, I was able to use Pinnacle Profiler to configure my 360 gamepad to play close to the original X-Box version, with a shift mode controlling the mouse pointer when I need it. Again, it took some toying and learning, but I was able to get it to the point where it works extremely well.

Not all is sunny and roses on the planet Taris, though. There are some odd graphical glitches from time to time. Also, some of the NPC's faces repeat or are similar enough to be jarring. In 8 hours of play with a few mods installed, I only experienced one crash to desktop (and of course, this could be related to having modded the files). There was also an annoying glitch in which my character would stop moving after battles, but this was fixed on my machine by enabling V-Sync.

However, the overall quality of the title is so absurdly high that these minor annoyances pale in comparison.

HIghest recommendations on this one. Do yourself a favor and enjoy this masterpiece classic.

reviewText:
Effectively the main inspiration behind the structure of Bioware's Mass Effect, KoTOR to me is one of the greatest RPG's I've ever played. Even ignoring being a fan of Star Wars overall, it seems detached from almost everything else that has been produced (The Old Republic being based off a similar time frame), movies especially, and brings a lot of new things, despite keeping that semi-familiar setting.

It shows it's age, though, with no widescreen video options, and (very surprisingly), no vanilla overhaul mod available to tweak it up. At the same time though, there's a big reason for that, and that is that it has very little in the way of bugs and problems, and looks good enough for a game over ten years old. Another big way of showing age is a lack of functions many have come to expect from RPG's, like some kind of auto-loot, there's no way to heal the entire party automatically.. But the variety of how you can approach situations is rather staggering (But rather expectable from Bioware nowadays)

Definitely a great game, would recommend it to anyone who wants to lose a few weeks to a rather engrossing classic.

reviewText: One of BioWare's earlier achievements, KOTOR's an easy game to criticize in retrospect. From the release of Baldur's Gate in 1998 to Mass Effect just 10 years later, most every RPG released by BioWare would follow the same mass-produced, literally by-the-books Hero's Quest outline—i.e., each game’s plot felt like a meeting of forced expectations, sometimes satisfying and sometimes mind-numbing in their predicted delivery—a choice that simultaneously made their products restrictive holds against and necessary stepping stones for advancing the depth possible in video game story-telling.\n\nBut who cares, right? KOTOR tells a generic Star Wars story with mostly generic Star Wars characters, meeting every generic Star Wars expectation a gamer could ask for right down to the tired, required lines, but it does so almost flawlessly, to such an extent that its seemingly pedestrian qualities make it among the most fun and accessible modern RPG experiences and Star Wars stories. In an age-old formula so noticeable and so repeated some players even refer to it as the BioWare Cliché
date:
a faceless variable with a background too vague and mysterious to be taken seriously, recognized by everyone around them as vitally important is thrown into the midst of a universal conflict against a threatening Force of Unfathomable Evil. As their life is turned upside down against their better judgment, they’re guided by close mentors friends, one of whose personality’s teeters on the edge of simply being Han Solo before he’s overcome by emotional turmoil (and the personality traits are thusly handed off to a snarky youngster and her wookie companion), the other a sassy, sexy Obi-Wan-Leia hybrid.* Through thick and thin, unsurprising twists and heart-wrenching betrayal, they form a series of close bonds and pass the required tests necessary to rid the galaxy of malice once and for all.

Dropping the vague references to clichés repeated, KOTOR stars a young nobody, canonically male, her past just barely customizable to the point of ineffectuality, being shipped under unspoken circumstances that end under the galaxy-wide Jedi Civil War igniting her hidden potential in the Force (à la Luke Skywalker) over an introduction spent making friends and escaping the occupied planet-city Taris. Under the tutelage of these newfound friends, she hones her skills in the Force, strained physically and morally under four major tests of heroism across beloved planets like Tatooine and Kashyyk. What she and her entourage seek, they seek in the footsteps of the Sith Lord Malak and his former master Revan—deceased: betrayal, Siths, &c.**—, piecing together an alien map in order to understand what massive power source drove those two to Team Slytherin, or, like, whatever.

Their fall is itself a story existing partially outside the game’s bounds, a series of events that took place after the culmination of the Mandalorian Wars—the galaxy’s previous Big Mistake and a war led by the war-mongering culture of Mandalore, a bone-headed, unlikeable civilization modeled after a single facet of humanity, their sole goal to enslave or destroy everyone just because. The backdrop of this war’s aftermath fuels the chaotic political state in KOTOR; it was a war in which the Jedi stood by, watching—idling on the decision of whether their place included interference—and yet a war won almost single-handedly the two previously-mentioned Jedi, rationalizing the need to defend freedoms and lives threatened by Mandalore’s conquest.

Krayt dragons, wookie tribes, life debts, Klingons, Jawas and their sandcrawlers, planets being razed from space, half-naked old men running around star ships, limitless sources of unimaginable power, lost alien civilizations, bland villains—KOTOR has everything you expect and love from a Star Wars tale, wrapped and guided by the massive conflict of good and evil fighting over mythopoeic indulgence. The central theme of mythology itself, abused by Lucas and now by BioWare, here works as a symbol of their aging morality mechanics. Following this game, treading those grey areas became a duty, even if it took a couple stories and universes to figure out how to present believably.

As an RPG born in 2003, it almost can’t help but tread that line between oldschool and new-, providing a strategic (but accessible, simplified) battle-management system that lets you plan the course of every encounter at your own pace, coupled with real-time decision-making and exciting action full of lasers and light sabers and lightning-quick force powers and, uhm, grenades, I guess—just with dice rolls, added and appreciated: beloved mechanic of chance in things past. The leveling system also stands as one of BioWare's most fluid and functional (opposed to, say, Mass Effect’s messy, meaningless overdose of options and numbers), letting players tread lines however customizable they can get to the point of breaking the game, i.e., as with many RPGs prior to this last generation, it’s not exactly difficult to customize your character to the point that whatever plot point is impassibly difficult, i.e., multiple save files are strongly suggested.

And as such an RPG, it took some shocking dares in character design: HK-47, the fan-favorite assassin droid prefaces every delivered line with the emotional intent behind them, creating a stir of always-contemptuous black humor and irony; and Jolee Bindo, whose entire presence—a good man sitting comfortably on the line between the series’ Dark and Light Sides, quick to point out the flaws (and outright stupidity) inherent in the tenets of the Jedi Knight code—hints at the brilliant postmodern deconstruction Star Wars would get in Obsidian's ambitious sequel. They let us know lead-author Drew Karpshyn was capable of a lot more than farting out game-y dialogue and fetch quests by the dozens even when limited by that bullet-point list of Quest-with-a-Q requirements.

That greyed-out line Jolee walks, also brings to the forefront major flaws in BioWare’s championship of the modern RPG format. Areas of grey don’t apply much outside of his character or even BioWare’s RPGs prior to Mass Effect 2, but the forceful impact of choice has been their calling card (& often selling point) since 1998. When choice arises in dialogue or action, the writers strive to bring the sense that you’re calling the shots, that you’re the acting force that shaping its conclusion. Those choices, unfortunately, amount to either following that path of charity and sacrifice defined by the Jedi code, or make your avatar sound like a cartoon jerk tossing out petty insults like candy--maniacal laugh included. Under this system, choices often amount to little more than variations on the lines “I’d love to help clothe and feed you!” or “I don’t have time for your stupid babble.” This never makes sense with whatever narrative is being told: E.g., Why would these characters follow these bad decisions? Why would this person fall in love with this monstrous cliché?

Are these aged mechanics and writing a bad thing? I would definitely argue No, despite the lingering force of Internet backlash BioWare gets from more critical players. The ambition driving this illusion of meaning in player choice has only improved and grown more bewilderingly ambitious with every game BioWare’s released, the massive steps taken between each a necessary movement culminating in (as of 2013) the phenomenon that is the Mass Effect trilogy, a series driven successfully by the player choice and personal involvement all their previous RPGs like KOTOR strived towards. It may have taken a lot of trial-‘n’-error gambits—still ongoing—but it doesn’t mean the errors are necessarily mistakes, and it certainly doesn’t mean they aren’t worth experiencing when they’re this danged fun.

reviewText:
KOTOR is a great game with an amazing story and character development as well as solid voice acting. Bioware has been crafting these aspects of games right for a long time.

This game also has a stellar sense of environment for its time in regards to the planets you visit: each area has a distinctive and memorable atmosphere and adjoining characters. The music, geography, encounters, and side-quests all make each area an amazing experience on its own.

The component that makes this game a must-own and a classic, however, is its story. The fact that you have true agency over certain situations through dialogue is engaging and makes for a unique gaming experience. The parts of the story that you don't have control over still create such a compelling narrative that truly inhibits emotion - something that many games tend to lack.

While no one needs another review to confirm that this game is a classic worthy of any and everyone's library, another voice to support is always helpful.

reviewText:
This is my number one game of all time, and I definitely don't say that lightly. I may not have a huge amount of hours on this, but that's only because I played this so much before it was on Steam. It's not perfect, but then no game is without faults. I love everything about the Star Wars expanded universe and this is the pinnacle of it, it rises high above the waste and filth that are 90% of Star Wars video games and stands proudly as an amazing story drive experience. Light Side or Dark side, you choose, it's all up to you and it will affect you're ending and which of your party members decide to stand with you.

I'm not normally a fan of turn based combat, but they nailed it right here, the animations, the visuals and the effects
do look quite dated now but believe me, at the time it was a sight to behold.

It's hard to give this a neutral critical review because it would be like insulting my child if I were to say too many negative things against it. I cannot recommend this game enough. BUY IT WHATEVER THE PRICE

Plus it has one of my favourite WTF moments in gaming.

reviewText:
There are two things I like most in the Star Wars universe - the sound of a lightsaber and the sound of an imperial interceptor in space!
Even in KOTOR doesn't have the latter, if still manages to keep up with the first condition, and the use of the Star Wars universe while simply expanding it and not getting into the thin constraints of the movie makes it so much more interesting and welcome to changes.

I'm not sure if KOTOR 1 has widescreen support, some modding might be necesarry.
