reviewText:
I avoided STAR WARS - Knights of the Old Republic (SWKotOR) for a long time. Long used to WASD gaming it has an unusual but fitting control system that you quickly get used to. I freely admit learning it was the only part of the game that wasn't smooth, and even saying that it's very quick to get used to.

Not long into SWKotOR I began to realise and regret that I didn't play it sooner. As a long-time STAR WARS fan, and with how much I enjoyed STAR WARS Jedi Knight - Jedi Academy & STAR WARS Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast on release date because of how well-made they were I should've known how good SWKotOR would be.

Even now I'm surprised with how well-written the game was. I couldn't stop playing it, couldn't wait to see how the relationships with the other characters would unfold, couldn't wait to get started on the next side quest.

The only gripe I had at all was that it was short - slowly pushing 100% of content played only took me a little over 40 hours.

After you get to grips with the different controls you're going to love it if you're a STAR WARS fan of any kind.

SWKotOR is an old, but superb game.

reviewText:
I don't know many hours this thing says I've played, but it's wrong. I got this game when steam didn't even exist and it is the epitome of what games ought to be: worth the damn money.

Obviously it's Star Wars, so it's got that whole world going for it, even if it is now part of a disavowed canon. But beyond that there isn't a lot happening that was ground breaking for RPGs (maybe the decision based morality system, but I am not certain about that). So why should you buy it and play a thousand hours?

The story.

It's a compelling story of redemption if you want it to be. It's a compelling story of fate if you want it to be. It's just whatever you want it to be. Add in all the mods currently available and it is literally whatever you want it to be. Also, the restored content mod adds originally designed items and quests that got left out because LA loves to rush their ♥♥♥♥ to the market before it's finished.

I mean, if you want to be a Jedi"
date: there are better games. Battlefront. Jedi Knight II. To an extent
recommended: the Force Unleashed series. All of these let you control more of the force powers and have something more akin to actual saber combat. But this game is all about the story:\n\nSith versus Republic
hoursPlayed: a band of warriors brought together to fight for (or against) peace
voteText: and a mysterious stranger recruited to help defeat (or supplant) the Sith apprentice become master
helpfulPercent: Darth Malak. You travel to worlds across the galaxy in order to figure out how the Sith are building their fleet more quickly than the Republic can defeat them. And with the addition of the "grey" Jedi
votesHelpful: those who are neither light nor dark
votesTotal: maybe you decide it's best to sweep away the remnants of the Galactic Republic and rule it yourself.\n\nI mean
votesFunny: it's not canon anymore anyway. Do what you want.\n\nRecommended Buy
commentsCount: but only on sale because it goes on sale so often. It's worth the extra money
column16: but I believe in you and your ability to exercise self-control until it's 75% off."

reviewText:
One of the greatest RPG's ever made, KoToR is not just that, but it'also the greatest Star Wars game ever made. It's a must play for Star Wars fans and Bioware fans. For Bioware fans, it's fairly similar in the formula of playing a character that is set on a task of saving the world/universe from the forces of evil, in this case, the Sith, while there is also the moral choice of following the dark side here, as well. But Bioware fans, more specifically, Mass Effect fans, will find it familiar for the numerous side quests, the collection of companions and taking two with you at a time. You get to a point where your companions travel through space with you on a ship and, like Mass Effect, the companions are located in various points of the ship.

Yes, I know, this game came out years before Mass Effect, but not everyone played it back then, and it should still appeal to a mass audience now. I'm glad the game is on Steam, as there are ways to get the game to play in full 1080 HD/16:9. It involves editing text files and running a patch, but it works and shouldn't be an issue, if you know what you're doing.

The plot, amazing. I shouldn't even have to talk about it. You play a soldier that wakes up in the middle of battle on a ship and you fight your way to the escape pods with your bunkmate. Along the way to escaping, you meet Carth, whom will become your closest ally for the rest of the game, and unfortunately, your bunkmate dies, sacrificing himself so you can escape. Carth, and yourself crashland on Taris in the escape pod, and from there, your wild adventure begins. From Taris, you find work, make money, figure out what's going on between the Republic and the Sith, meet various companions, the Big Z (a wookie) and Mission (a twi'lek). You meet the mercenary Canderous and eventually you get to learn how to race and finally, you meet Bastila, a Jedi who becomes your second closest companion.

There are more companions in the game, but I'd be diving into the story and other planets. As for your character, you uncover the fact that you are strong in the force and train to become a Jedi. And soon, you're on a  mission to save the world from the evil Sith, and Darth Malak, a formidable foe, and one hell of a boss. (I died too many times on the final fight, prepare to have plenty of medpacs)

Overall, this game was insanely awesome.

10/10

reviewText:
I will always remember the first time Jolee Bindo told me the 'boy and the snake' story. It was a perfect bit of writing, ending with my very dodgy-looking Jedi (pale skin, yellowing eyes, red lightsaber) asking him, 'Am I supposed to be the snake?' He says, 'Well now, that's what I came to find out'.

--

KotOR is mostly an interactive story, and a really magical one. The writing is slightly dated by the standards set by Bioware's more recent hits, often slightly 'videogame-y' and always less cinematic than the likes of Mass Effect, but it's still just amazing. The combat is semi-turn based - very similar to Dragon Age: Origins or the recent Pillars of Eternity - but it's a lot of fun. And if you've ever wanted to play a game where Bioware absolutely live up to their promises and potential for once, then this is it. It's the one that put them on the map.

It's also the game to play if you're looking for that 'feel like you're in Star Wars' quality that games like Battlefront and Jedi Knight come so close to capturing but don't quite get. In an average 30-40 hour playthrough of KotOR you can expect to save / condemn the galaxy, ride swoop bikes, manipulate beaurocats and dodge docking fees with the Jedi mind trick, leap halfway across a map to cut sand-people in half, convert a lost dark Jedi back to the light (or the opposite), buy an assassin droid who calmly tells you how every single one of his former owners died by his hands and just how much he enjoyed it, and argue with all manner of space-Nazis about every facet of space-racism. It feels very 'Star Wars' and very 'Bioware' at the same time, but the two never clash.

What the game does best is in breathing life and weight into the 'good versus evil' meter that so many RPGs had back then, and some still maintain shadows of (i.e. Mass Effect, The Walking Dead). KotOR's devs and writers were aware that they had the Star Wars licence for this one and that their story was supposed to be about Jedi knights. They took full advantage of the 'lure of the dark side' angle, allowing the cruelty or generosity of your actions to be meaningful and to form the centre of a game's story and theme. Who your character becomes is crucial to the plot, so deciding who to torture with lightning and who to donate money to makes all the difference in the world. It all builds up to a single brilliant decision and two very distinct, very satisfying endings. The game knows exactly what was so great about Star Wars and The Empire Strikes Back (Vader, Yoda, the hero's journey, the dark side, the Falcon, the love story, the big twist, the world-building, the witty banter) and it lovingly packs it all in.

--

A polished, large, joyful Star Wars replica. It gets everything 'just right'.

reviewText:
Statement: The RPG that made Bioware famous to non-PC gamers may have one of the most spoiled game stories ever. Spoilers are why I didn't finish for 9 years, and much like ESB, the impact is less if you know ahead of time. But KOTOR isn't just one of the first great Western console RPGs.

Explanation: In 2003, two Star Wars prequels & The Matrix Reloaded left many dejected. This was the blockbuster people WANTED. There had been Star Wars games before, but here was a setting wholly untouched by George Lucas. Though much is evocative of the original films, many of the NPCs are rough drafts for Mass Effect's.

Observation: The setting hides many of Bioware's now-maligned shortcomings; here the binary morality makes sense. The Bioware romance" can't really come into full effect either. But sci-fi trappings aside it's literally D&D for all the clunkiness that entails. I grew up on Baldur's Gate
date: so I can deal.\n\nConclusion: The assassin droid HK-47 is the greatest. Play for him
hoursPlayed: March 5, 2012

reviewText:
Here is my review of Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic.

As a huge Star wars fan it surprises me that it took me so long to play this game. I recently picked it up in the steam christmas sale for like 3 bucks. I played a couple days later to see how good it actually was. to be honest at first I absolutely hated it. the combat style was completely new to me and I had no idea about anything in the old republic era of star wars so I closd the game and didn't play it for another month. I opened it back up convinced that this game was something. I mean most people say that this is the greatest Star wars game ever, let alone rpg ever.

I beat this game a couple hours ago and I have to say that this has been the best Star Wars game I have ever played in my life. Number one this game has an insane amount of content in it. I beat the main storyline in about 30 hours. Most games that hae come out recently don't have a storyline this long. The characters in this game are absolutely awesome to learn about and get to know through the game. the game incorporates a kind of moral system where decisions you make in the game effect whether you go to the dark side and go to the light side. This game has a very cool combat system (was you get the hang of it.) It is turn based so most people (at least me) was not used to this type of system. The graphics are very dated yes, but the game is by far playable. I honestly didn't really have a problem with them. But the best part of the game is that it feels completely star wars" I really did feel as if I was imersed in the world of Star Wars.

Now for cons of this game. In my opinion there isn't that many cons. The only ones I can think of is that your "bag" i guess or where you hold items in endless you can hold a million items if you wanted to which is cool but the items aren't very organized which is the con in this case. My other con is that after I beat the game I planned on doing all of the leftover side quests but when I beat it just rolled credits and I wasn't allowed to go back and do other things in the game which kind of annoyed me.

My final rating of this game would have to be 10/10."

reviewText:
Bioware RPG's always have a special feel, and they are great to play.

I finished this game a second time now, the first time I played it was as it was fresh and mint out of developement. Now, so many years later it hasn't lost it's apeal. The story and it's developement, the many hints that can give you the creeps - and still keep you guessing. Once again a good roleplaying game under the licence of Lucas Arts: Star Wars Trademark.

Graphically dated, but yes there is an upgrade downloadable, there are also some unofficial mods to this game. The game itself is sealed in its story, there is no need to bugger around a lot - because the riddles and minigames are selfexplanatory. Being a Jedi can be quite a hard job at times... Decissions, decissions, decissions... and though some decissions can be quite deadly, others are more aimed at your preference about light and darkness. This time I decided to become a paragorn of the Light side... and, well, let's just say Revan" died this time once and for all.

Being a Jedi doesn't mean that you can't use subterfuge or clandestine ops - but you have to make sure that you help others with it

reviewText: I would say that aged badly. reviewText:
(I may only have 5 or so hours on this but I have the game on disc copy and burned out my first set of discs so I've played a ton)

This is in my opinion one of the greatest games ever made, definatlly one of the best RPG's ever

It is a game that fits amazing character interaction and plot development, into a world where you can more or less explore as you wish. You are not tied to your main character, if you want you could use one of the party memebers you meet as the character you control even.

Combat is unuiqe, a mix bettween RTS and Turn Based at the same time, allowing for fast paced action or slow methodical planning, which ever you prefer.

One of the things I liked is that there is a stat measure of your light or darkness, and your choices determine where that falls. If it's too light certian options are closed to you, or vice versa.


My only complaint with this game is that it's old, so the graphics aren't the best, and it doesn't support modern resolutions; a fairly small complaint for a game.

Overall I'd say KOTOR is worth the $10, probobly even worth twice that.

Now what're ya waitin for, go get it, and don't forget to load up your atro droid with flamethrowers and take control of 'im XD

reviewText:
This is really a must have for Star Wars fans. In my opinion it's way better than KOTOR 2. It is much more challenging to play as a Light Side, because of difficult choices, instead of killing everything that goes on your path and become Sith Lord.

There are some not satisfying things in this game. It includes a LOT of running from one place to another, which can be boring. Even there is a fast travel, it's limited to your hideout/ship and location you currently are. Also, being bounty hunter or just regular person with range weapon is pointless, since you are Jedi/Sith.

All in all, this is one of the best SW games ever.

10/10

reviewText:
I've attempted to play this game 4 times. Every time I hated it, but now I love it.

When I first played this game I liked Star Wars, I was interested in it alot. I wasn't very patient and I really never gave it a chance. Now I love Star Wars, and I gave it a chance and it was amazing, by far one of the best Star Wars games I've ever played. It takes a while to get past the boring start, but once you really get into the campaign the story is so gripping and exciting.

This game is years old, but has aged well along with Battlefront 2. May the Fourth be with you sale is active right now, so you can get this game pretty cheap, along with any other Star Wars game on Steam.

I've had the entire collection for a while now, but I would recommend this game to any Star Wars fan.

reviewText: 10 years later, still one of my favorite games.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Rating 7.5/10
Overview: Turn Based RPG

The Good

+ The game has a lot of robust options in how you build your character. You start by choosing between 3 classes, soldier, scout or scoundrel. Each class obviously focuses on different aspects of combat. Further in the game you can then choose the Jedi you wish to be: Guardian, Consular or Sentinel. You can fully customize your character how you wish between attributes, skills, feats and jedi powers. All of this leads to many different options and replaybility in how you design your character

+The core aspect of the game is that as you can either play as a Jedi that is good or evil. Saving people, being kind and choosing the peaceful solution leads you to the light side while doing the opposite leads you to the darkside. Doing so leads to certain bonuses to your Jedi Powers. Being good means Lightside powers will use less mana and darkside powers cost more and viceversa. I find the system to be very effective because it ties morality choices into gameplay, a feature that seems to be very lacking in today's modern games.

+The game supports a solid story that is engaging throughout the entire game. Dialogue is well done although a bit heavy on exposition in the beginning.

+As is the case with every Bioware game, the supporting cast of characters are interesting and unique and features some of the best writing in the game. Getting to know your companions and there back stories is one of the highlights of the game.

+The game has plenty of interesting sidequests that are fun to play and depending on how you solve them really start to shape your character. I wish there was more ambiguity with the quests because it becomes very obvious which is the good and evil way to solve them. A moral grey area would have made choices tougher to make.

+ The game takes place across a series of planets within the Star Wars universe. Each location feels different from the last and has a rich back story that just adds to the authenticity.


The Average

Combat in the game is basic, simply select your choice of attack then watch and hope your character can actually connect with a hit. It doesn't feel very engaging especially in the later parts of the game when you become really powerful.

The game had many graphical glitches and bugs in certain areas that made it difficult to play.

Final boss is frustrating

There are a lot of areas in the game that feel big and empty.

The Bad

The UI especially navigating to find items in your inventory is a chore and frustrating. The inventory screen is a long list of your items. Finding a specific item can be problematic, for example, if you find a data pad and want to read it, you have to open your inventory scroll through a long list of items until you find it. If you have other datapads in your inventory that you haven't checked yet then you have to check each one until you find the one you're looking for. There are options to filter the list based on specific items but this doesn't fix the overall problem of a bad overall inventory management system.

Conclusion

I have played this game many times before it came on steam and having it in my library I decided to play it again to see how well it holds up and I was pleasantly surprised. This game feels like the blueprint for Mass Effect as it shares many similarities in its design choices.

reviewText:
Great game, but unplayable on modern OS's. Every fix presents a new problem. I had 5 seperate and gamebreaking issues plus some within an hour of gameplay. Buy the game on your smartphone instead, it's exactly the same, but works better.

Issues (since people are asking):
-Constant crashing
-Scaling issues on high resolution
-Hud disappeared permanently after attempting to fix the crashing (which didn't work anyways)
-Disgusting performance on good system (about 15-30 fps on the endar spire)
-Getting stuck after some combat situations
-Cursor inches off center making it almost impossible to select anything
-Cursor not working at all sometimes
-No widescreen support (the fixes didn't work, and if they did the hud would be distorted)

reviewText:
Since the original posting of this review there now appear to be more trouble shooting resources than ever before. Steam has also improved refunds. I still do not recommend the steam version from personal experience and have had better success and instant playability with the GoG version on three separate computers.

If you don't like trouble shooting this game probably isn't for you.
I have found KotOR to be near impossible to play through steam. Some people may not have much trouble starting it but a majority are not able to get this game to run without spending a significant amount of time troubleshooting. The first time two years ago after nearly an hour of trying fixes the game finally ran after character creation. I was about two minutes in  but could not figure out how to progress. Turns out it was bugged. More troubleshooting and I manage to finally get to the next part of the mission only for it to be bugged again. After a few hours I could not get the game at any more playable of a state. One year later I give it another shot and this time I can't even get the first mission to load. Close to four hours of work and I manged to play five minutes of the game.

reviewText: This is my first time writing a review ever. I will first start out with how this is one of my favorite game titles from the sixth generation of console's. I was never a true Star Wars game or movie fan, sure I played some games like; star Wars BF 1&2, Star Wars Republic Commando which I would also recommend to any Star Wars fan. Now the KotoR series shows a deep connection not to the history made by George Lucas(not to discredid the man since I do not know how much he has contributed to the historical lore of his series) which the fanbase has mostly made for the accounting matters of most stories before and after the Star Wars Saga(all 6 movies). This Game was the second Star wars game I fell in love with after the first few hours of playing on the original Xbox. The mechanics were something I never really liked in most games and I admit I shrugged it off in terms of not wanting to play it since it went far off what I was used to for gameplay. The story, the Characters, the complete immersion of the destinies of people you interact with that could alter the fate of an entire planet quicker than you would have known of in a game like this. In short I really love this and KotoR II. Because of this game in particular, I have started down the evil path in all decision based games with a morality center like Jade Empire. then I just do everything different on the next playthrough. A lot of the game is laughable in today's sense of Modern Gaming" or in the everything about the game's graphical engine and motor physics of the semi-turn-based combat which was as close to a then modern miracle/innovative as it could be at the time in "my" opinion. So yea

reviewText: This is one the greatest games that I have ever played. I originally played KOTOR II on the original Xbox; it was one the best video game experiences I've ever had despite some of the issues with the game. Nearly 9 years later I started using steam and I noticed the KOTOR series on sale. I bought the two games and I must say that was the best decision I've made in a long time. Let me start off with a brief synopsis for those who are unaware of the story of KOTOR I. You essentially play a character with no background. Your first mission is to find a Jedi named Bastilla who was onboard the ship that you were on when it got attacked. Once you rescue her and escape with your new crew, you begin to learn the way of the Jedi on Dantooine. You get to choose the path you want to travel: the light side or the dark side. There is an evil sith lord named Malak who must be stopped, so you can either save the galaxy or become one of the most powerful sith lords. The choice is yours. Along the way you will befriend people and maybe lose them depending on your choices. Now I'm not going to go much more into the story; that is for you to discover dear reader.\n\nIf you are a Star Wars fan, then get this. You can't call yourself a fan without having played this game. If you love RPGs, then get this game. Some issues are the d20 combat system that might seem unengaging and annoying at times. The story is a bit too black and white, but keep in mind that the Star Wars series in general has held a black and white morality viewpoint. This was just a minor issue for me because I had played KOTOR II before this game and it seemed to do a better job at making the morality of both the Jedi and the Sith greyish. The game might also seem a bit dated now, but trust me it holds up fairly well. The sheer mythology of Star Wars should be enough for you to buy this game. Even if you don't consider yourself a Star Wars fan, you will still enjoy this game. I hope this review answers any questions you had. Now I have a question for you: why are you wasting your time reading this when you should be playing KOTOR?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?

reviewText: Overall, I would rate KotOR 8/10 and most definetely one of the greatest RPG titles out there!  Knights of the Old Republic focuses on the span of time after the Mandalorian Wars of the Old Republic, and follows a soldier with little recollection of their past.  The graphics are pretty well done, best enchanced with mods (I have tons of awesome mods on mine that add in content and bring in hd graphics), the gameplay is simple and well executed, and the storyline is a great one to add to your Star Wars repitoee (sp?)  There are some things that sort of get left behind for your character, such as melee weapons and ranged weapons and combative skills that go with them once you become a Jedi (or Sith if that's what you want to role-play) however they still help your companions.  The companion system is great, allowing either 0,1, or 2 companions - be sure to check with all of them for specific content related to your companions!  One game-breaking bug that should be mentioned... try to do Tattoine last if at all possible.  There is a companion mission that leads you to tatooine that gets broken if you have gone to particular places before getting the quest - I could provide more info but that would be a spoiler.  Pick up this great game and have fun!
